Yeah, it doesn't have programmable RGB lighting and the dark gray matte isn't appealing to the eye, but the dang thing works perfectly and that's what really matters.
Endless issues on Mac. I shouldn't have to be troubleshooting a mouse every day in 2020.

Why buy a mouse with multiple functions? To make your life easier when working with it. NOT with this mouse. Forget about using this with a MAC. Every extra button will fail you aside from the regular 1 and 2 click buttons. Buy a $10 mouse for that. The software with Apple OS will drive you F'ing insane. So don't waste your cash. No support. No refund by the time it screws you over. Do not waste your cash on this for its extra features. Period. Used to be a Logi guy, no longer.
Makes dancing around my screen a snap, does a great job, lots of features.
I like it for standard MS Office apps. Jury’s still out on Creo MCAD use.

I really wanted to love this mouse. I loved everything about it, ergonomics, buttons, the feel of the wheels etc... however there is a huge dealbreaker: the scrolling is buggy as hell. I have now tried two different mx master 3's and both had issues with scrolling. For example when scrolling up it would "skip" scrolls every few turns of the wheel causing my scrolling to stop on my computer then start again, quite often after scrolling the wheel will bounce back a bit and cause me to reverse direction ever so slightly etc... I tried all different kinds of settings and made sure my firmware was updated but no dice the issues remained. After going through two of them with the same issue I can't recommend anyone buys this. What a shame... If you don't believe me just google "mx master 3 scroll issues".

First you feel how heavy it is. It's like 3-4 times more heavy than any other mouse. Clicks are bit too loud and haptic feedback from wheel is too strong (or non-existing if you turn it off). I returned this mouse because under heavy laptop load it stutters and lags. Even the cheapo wireless mouse I have now works much better than this mouse.

I purchased this mouse in hopes that I can skip using a dongle with my thin USB-C laptop by switching to bluetooth connection. It does not work! Slightly better ergonomics compared to my still-working Performance MX, but it does not worth the $100! I cannot believe that Logitech would sell something so obviously flawed. Good old Logitech is dead--just the Logi part remains, but the tech is gone!

I really, really wanted to like this mouse.  It fits my hand like a glove, and I love the extra buttons, having just come from a very basic USB mouse.  It had such a nice hand feel, and although the thumb button is pretty useless as it's very difficult to press without pushing the mouse all over the place, I can live without it, especially since I can't map that button as I'll describe below. Also, the battery life is quite good.  I think I can generally get about 2 weeks or more on a full charge, using the mouse for probably 12 hours per day. The scroll wheels are fairly good, with a decent response, though I do see some odd jitter and lag from time to time, and the position of the thumb scroll wheel can be a bit awkward.But, that is, unfortunately where my joy for this mouse ends.  First, it's not a Linux mouse, despite the claim.  Yes, after plugging it into a Linux system, the pointer moves around and the buttons work (this is not unique as the protocols for basic mouse functionality work in pretty much any modern Linux kernel, and you should be able to pretty much plug any mouse you find in and have it work at this level).  But, the software designed to accompany the mouse and allow to to adjust the functionality, button mapping to applications, monitor the battery, etc. can not be installed on Linux, and you have to try to find some other 3rd party hacks as a surrogate. So, for example, I can not map the thumb button to anything, and am stuck with it in the default action, which is to swap between open applications like an Alt + Tab keyboard shortcut.  But, if you don't care about knowing the battery level and mapping the buttons to your liking, I guess that's not a big deal?Worse, the connectivity, whether it be though the WiFi or Bluetooth connection is awful.  I am constantly having dropouts, lag, and inconsistent responsiveness that is beyond frustrating.  This mouse is not at all, in any way, shape, or form usable for gaming.  And, even for just general office work, it can be maddening to have it jumping around while you're trying to cut and paste data in a spreadsheet, or click on the correct link in a webpage.  About 75% of the time it may work fine - even, arguably great.  But, then, for some unknown reason, it will just start flaking out and be useless for the next few hours.  I still have my 10 year old basic USB mouse connected just so that I can swap over to that when the mouse feels like flaking out.This mouse is expensive, and as such, I would have expected a much, much better user experience and performance.  It seems as though, many other users are seeing the same thing based on the reviews.  So, hopefully Logitech will figure out what's going on and either release a patch to correct the bad behavior (along with a supported Linux application!), or send out a better unifying receiver or something to address the spotty connectivity.In short, save your money and look for a more reliable and better built mouse, as this one is not nearly worth the cost.  And, if you are running Linux and want a full native experience, don't believe the claim on the box that it's a Linux mouse - it's not.
Great mouse but not sure if it worth the price.....

For some reason , the mouse wasn't connecting well via bluetooth connection, but using the dongle made it magical. Everything about the mouse is superb. By and far the best mouse I have ever used. Only con is the price ! :)

I am using this mouse simply for productivity and it is hands down the best mouse I have ever used. It's not only incredibly comfortable, it's also very functional and has fantastic software. I own mice by both Steelseries and Razer... and while they certainly have an emphasis on gaming, they do not lack features. Neither are half as ergonomic as the MX Master 3 and neither have software that is even close to as customizable. Before using the MX Master 3, I had not given Logitech much of my focus. But I will never use another mouse... if this wears out, I will simply buy another.

Update below. Bluetooth is finally working (fix included), and no skips and jittery behavior.---Original review---I had been having troubles with another Logitech MX mouse skipping and misbehaving. I chalked it up to that one being about ten years old, so I got this MX Master 3 since I really do like the feel and general usability of Logitech mice. Unfortunately this one also exhibited the exact same motion issue: stuttering, skipping, incredibly frustrating pauses. I had a look into the Logi forum and it appears to be interference with other wifi devices. I attempted to place the receiver very close to the mouse (it's on a USB extension cable now) and that failed to completely address the issue, though it seems to help a bit.I then tried the bluetooth interface, since that uses an entirely different frequency, protocol, everything...and that had even worse performance than the wifi interface. That could be my particular mouse, or my BT receiver, who knows. I'm simply resigned to poor performance from an otherwise mostly nice mouse. The roller initially performed exactly as described: hyper-fast, like mindblowingly extreme-fast. That has slowed now to scrolling at sub-par, very likely due to dust and cat fur. That brings me to another issue, namely the challenge in servicing this hardware. The maintenance-free, quite nice slick pads on the bottom are there in part to obscure screws, and getting the pads back on and still having them smooth and not catch on the mousepad, is a challenge, just as with older Logitech mice. At some point it's a losing battle, and I believe one must buy a set of new pads.I really want to like this mouse. I like the conveniently located fwd/back thumb buttons. I *liked* the hyperscroll, until it slowed to a crawl -- not its fault per se, but it should have been designed to have a closed hub to inhibit clogs. I like the feel of the button-presses, and I really like that the hyperscroll is button-selectable between clicking and free spin. But again, the free spin is not stellar if the wheel's hub becomes clogged. If you have a really clean house, no pets, no dust, hardwired ethernet, this is a superb mouse. Maybe your BT will work better than mine did, and you won't have stuttering. If you have fur, dust and so on, prepare to service this mouse with some frequency.---additional content---Bluetooth jitter and issues has been cleared up in Arch Linux via installing a blueZ compatibility layer. It also turns out that the unifying receiver cannot be plugged in and have bluetooth connectivity work. This is not documented well, or at all, in the documentation or on the Logitech website. I had to unplug the unifying receiver, switch the mouse button (underside) first toward the center of the mouse, then back up, then hold the 1-2-3 button to make visible. There's no documentation that states that this button acts as a bluetooth pairing button; it's always called a 'channel' button and that's in the context of the unifying receiver.Bad documentation both online and with the device. But I'm upping to a 4-star since it's finally working. The wheel issue is a drag on a 5-star.

A worthwhile fit, just right to fill my boxer hand. It’s a bit heavy but it really doesn’t bother me. Have been using it for graphic design and it’s splendid. Superb battery life, charged it only once since I bought it but can’t remember when.

My son bought this mouse for me from another store and paid full price, i.e. $99+tax. I loved the mouse until the scroll wheel broke. I contacted Logitech and they agreed that it is broken. However, more than 1 month has passed and I still didn't get a replacement. I am working from home and depend on this mouse. A non-working scroll wheel is making my work a lot more difficult. I bought a lot of stuff from Logitech but (mice, keyboards, speakers, remote controls) but when you have a problem they won't support you...
Just feels nice to hold and the buttons are positioned in a really intuitive way

I extensively tried all options researching online, the scroll doesn’t work at all., tried other machine, same results. Whats the use if you pay over 100 if your mouse just work like basic mouse.

This mouse seems to be a downgrade from its previous version. Since I misplaced my Master 2S, I was pleasantly noted that there is a newer version, so I happily ordered one.  What a mistake. It feels lighter, smaller, and cheaper.  The extreme annoy thing is that since it is lighter, and its bottom is extremely slippery, it is very easy to be moved. As such the mouse pointer is very hard to be controlled, the pointer tends to always overshoot its locations.  Very unhappy.

4-month review: boo! I can't stand it anymore.There is no way to turn off the free-wheeling clutch mechanism, which turns on and off by itself and keeps the scroll wheel rolling long past when it should. Buy the MX 3 if you want your web pages to suddenly zoom into 800% magnification, apps to mysteriously cycle through all its tabs over and over, and for your finger to go noticeably numb from being used as a brake against the ridges in the scroll wheel.Speaking of pain, expect about 30 unintended clicks an hour do to the uncomfortably light touch on the buttons which cause you to have to "hover" above the buttons rather than rest on them, which will lead to muscle fatigue and pain in your flexi carpi radialis (specifically). It's a wholly inferior mouse to the much cheaper Logitech M720, and it doesn't match the quality and design of Logitech's keyboard in the same product line, the MX Keys. Don't be fooled by the gee-whiz gimmicks of this mouse. This is not the mouse you are looking for. Move along.

I've used every generation of MX Master mice and this is a great blend of the previous variants. I love the ability to scroll both vertically and horizontally. Thank you for returning the thumb wheel - missed it in the previous generation.

Nice Mouse if it stayed working correctly Mine is less than a year old and constantly looses focus. It needs to be moved back & forth rapidly to find the cursor. I have replaced the unifying receiver and relocated it to different usb ports. Still the same problem. I have purchased numerous Logitech products and this is the first one to give me problems .

The mouse itself has good build quality (which you'd expect considering the price), but it's built so it should last some time. The batteries can also be replaced if they hit too many recharge cycles. The mouse doesn't come with a manual or anything so figuring out the bluetooth required a quick google search but nothing too bad. The  Logitech software that gets auto-installed in the newest versions of Windows 10 is really well done. It's easy to customize most of the buttons and functionality as well as do different and unique customizations for each application.
Great mouse. Ergonomically comfortable and of good quality
This mouse broke within the warranty period and Logitech is being crazy slow to replace or communicate with me.  Very bad service, and this will impact my decision to buy Logitech again.

The side scroller does not work consistently when mapped to scroll horizontally within apps even when configured through the Logitech Options tool. This makes a key defining feature on an expensive mouse largely useless. Equally as useless is Logitech support as they will have you troubleshoot the mouse over and over before offering to replace the unit. Logitech needs to fix the actual problem and make the feature work consistently and reliably. The company still makes great mice but this is not one of them. Avoid and go with something less gimmicky.
Fantastic, well made mouse

I had such high hope for this mouse.  Some reviews indicated issues with connectivity for Mac users, but I hoped a software update would fix that.  No.  The mouse lagged and skipped and made working a very real chore.  I visited forums and even called Logitech for troubleshooting assistance.  But, in the end, could not resolve the issues.  Returning this and DO NOT recommend if you are a Mac user.

First one purchased had major issues staying connected to receiver.  Plagued with lagging and stuttering.  Received a replacement and same issue a few days after receiving.  Ensured is was fully charged and it still would stutter... flip it over and the number would be blinking, like it was trying to connect.  So disappointed.  Have quite a few Logitech products and this... the most expensive product I’ve purchased from them... failed.  Was tempted to just use it wired because it felt so good... but not at that price.
Mouse broke in less than a year. Seller won't help, amazon won't help and the manufacturer is useless.

I've been using logitech mouses and keyboard for at least a decade. When this whole work from home thing started, decided to get me fancy ergonomic muse for home office. MX Master 3 seemed like an obvious choice. What a disappointment. The most annoying part - it keeps loosing connection to my laptop (Windows 10), and I have to reboot in order to reconnect the mouse. Couple of times a week. Seems like not a big deal, but so frustrating. Ergonomic is kind of questionable. I guess it is just me, but after almost three months using this thing I cannot really tell that it is much better than cheaper alternatives.

class="cr-original-review-content">hola tenia un dolor en la muñeca por el uso de un mouse inadecuado para las horas que uso mi Mac, mi informe de las cosas que podía hacer para aliviar el dolor y una fue cambiar de mouse por uno ergonómico y pensado para darle soporte a la muñeca y me hice con el Logitech MX Master 3 100% X 100% recomendado.

Product is A1, precise, adjustable, and ergonomic buttons. I have big hands so my Apple Magic Mouse wasn’t cutting it. This is a very comfortable mouse for normal use, photoshop, and I do light gaming, not sure how it would do with heavy shooters

I'm disappointed not only of this product but of logitech company overall. It used to be a great company, but not anymore. Now let's go though issues.* Due to electromagnetic design of scroll wheel, fast scrolls are not registered!  Firmware update does not help.* You can't upgrade firmware without unifying receiver, which can be easily lost due to it's size, and it also occupies 1 usb slot.* Logitech software is not user friendly, and badly designedFirmware update tool does not show what's the firmware version, in order to see it you have to install logitech unifying softwareSo I ended up installing 3 software packages!! Just for one mouse ? Really logitech ?

How many computers do you have in your house?  I have four that I use regularly.Now that I've used this mouse, I want one for every computer I use.  Three more at home, and two at work.Great mouse. I wish it was less expensive.
Love this wireless mouse!
Love it!!!
It generates wrist annoying pain, which I didn't have with the old version of MX.

How the heck are we in 2020 with all USB C iPads and MacBooks, that Logitech is still not including USB Dongles. The bluetooth is hella laggy and you gotta turn off and on the mouse to reset the Bluetooth connection 🤦‍♂️ SMH
after having the MX Master for 6 years its a nice upgrade with a familiar tactile experience.

This was a great mouse when I first received it. After only 7 months, the mouse now registers phantom clicks when I’ve only clicked once. I’ve tried cleaning it and every troubleshooting step Logitech recommends to no avail. What makes matters worse is that their online warranty claim sends you right back to the instruction manual which is useless. Now I have to try and find time to call their customer service line.
High quality mouse. Fits perfectly in the hand. Love the Action and feel of the metal scroll wheels.  Really happy with this purchase!

I don't know if this is allowed but I'm going to do it anyway in hopes this will help in your decision on what mouse to by. So I read reviews of all different types of mice for about six days before settling on this MX3 masters mouse. I found it cheaper on a different website so i did not purchase this product from Amazon I won't say the site but if you got to this site I'm sure you know how to use GOOGLE. Anyway I work from home but I am not a huge computer person. I don't game or any of that stuff. I just like a quality product that makes my life easier and this mouse does exactly that. It seems that Logitech has thought of everything for this mouse. It has more than i need but when has having more than you need ever been a real quality problem. If you are looking for a great mouse look no further. It feels solidly made, It's been a week and I have been on the computer much more than usual and the battery says it basically still fully charged. Super easy to set up. Pretty much take it out of the box and use it! There is a great tutorial which for me was great because like I said i'm not a big computer person. don't want to rant but my opinion is this mouse is great! Good job Logitech.

I got this to replace my original MX.  So I've been wanting it for a while.  I love the magnetic wheel.  It will rip through thousands of rows in one flick of the wheel.  The thumb, left to right, wheel is a great feature too.  The top of the mouse that sits in the deepest part of the palm is a tiny bit thinner than the original MX.  My hand feels like that part of the palm is working just to smallest bit harder. The thumb gesture button is just off being in a natural position for my thumb.  I wish it came with a profile for revit.  Literally the only downside is that the mouse click is a little louder and a little more higher pitch than the original MX.  But that's full on nitpicking.  Overall the mag wheel makes up for any downside.  That alone will save my hand from a lot of work.

For me the number one feature for a mouse is ergonomics. This mouse just feels great in my hand! The placement of the buttons are well thought out and it just works great. I use this mouse for work (CAD/CAM) but I would think it would also be a good gaming mouse. I only had it for 2 weeks and the battery has not needed a recharge. Good job LOGI, great design!

I recently bought this mouse for my mac, as it is advertised as the "mx master mouse for mac". I've had issues with the original mx master (version 1), where the scroll stopped working on MacOS catalina. I bought this mouse in hopes that Logitech has addressed this software or hardware issue. I am very unhappy with this purchase as I spent $100 for a product that does not even scroll.This seems to be an ongoing issue with logitech. I had the original MX master mouse back in mid 2019 and it worked fine for a year, then it stopped working with the new OS (catalina). Since March, there have been no software updates that have alleviated this issue. I bought this new mouse, as it is advertised as a mouse for mac, and the scroll doesn't work. $100 for a mouse that doesn't scroll.. On top of that, logitech's customer service is so bad. They put you through ongoing loops and transfers until you just give up with trying to find a solution. Going to return this as soon as possible.

The battery does not hold up there support is crap and there excuses is Covid Mouse wont hold charge it is red the whole time.  For $105 could have get something more reliableLogitech is not like it used to be 30 mins on hold and no progress.

This mouse causes me discomfort in minutes. Not a good fit for my hand. But it does have a nice rubber grip, nice texture to the buttons, nice clickiness, fun scroll wheel (I don't experience the scroll issues others mention, perhaps those have been addressed) alas, all for naught in my case. For reference, I find the microsoft sculpt ergonomic mouse a very natural fit in my hand.
Scroll wheel was totally dysfunctional. Skipped scrolls, randomly jumped around.
Comfortable and easy to use. Responsive

I didn't use this for gaming, just everyday desktop usage. The scroll wheel is faulty. I thought maybe it needed to "learn" my usage pattern, then it would work better but instead it's gotten a lot worse. 2 months old, and I can't even really use it anymore, and I'm out of the return window. Overpriced and defective.

Works like a charm across all my devices. Charge seemingly lasts forever. WAY more comfortable than the magic mouse!! The scroll is a bit funky on iPad Pros but that's an apple issue not Logitech. Best wireless mouse on the market.

I bought the MX Vertical (see my review on this).  but returned it to get this MX Master 3. This one is great as it's your traditional mouse but with a lot more functionality. See Logitech website or video for all it's features.  I connect via Bluetooth and charge it with the USB cable it comes with. There is also the micro USB to connect with but I don't use it as I am limited to 2 USBs on my laptop. I connect both my Logitech ERGO K860 keyboard via Bluetooth too. I am a tax accountant so this mouse allows me to move through PDFs, tax software, Excel, online tax organizers, and Outlook perfectly. There is a functionality pre programmed to move from tabs within documents but am still trying to figure out how to move backward.  Seems it goes to the next page in PDF but won't go back to previous page. Anyway, I recommend this mouse even though it's really expensive. Think of it as a long term purchase when you depreciate it by $25 each year. Well worth it.
It is worth the money to purchase this mouse.
Works great when using to record music.

What a difference this mouse makes for me! I have been using a flat mouse and have been having some hand pain in my thumb joint and fatigue from being at my computer all day.  This mouse has help tremendously.  It takes the stress off my hand and I could really tell the difference from day one.  Also...it looks cool and I like the ratchet scrolling roller.

We've all had plenty of mouse(s).  Doesn't sound right to say "mice" since this isn't really a living thing.  Regardless, it's the best I've ever owned.  I scroll wheel is especially of high quality.  It's a nice, hard metal/plastic component that has a "click" feel (without the click sound) when you scroll.  If you speed up your scroll to much faster it actually falls into a freefall mode where the click goes away and it feels incredibly smooth and has a bit of inertia.  What I mean is that it doesn't stop scrolling, it continues on its own, until you stop it with your finger.  As a software developer I find myself inside files with thousands of lines of code and this has served as an excellent way to rapidly navigate up/down to where I want to get.I recommend this mouse with zero hesitation.

Its usually hard to review something top opf the line the only thing i could write is if there was something wrong with it.Scrolling thousand lines in 1 second ad flipping through tabs with simple sidescroll in invaluable for programming.The only thing wrong that i do not get is how to remap multi functional thumb button to program specific tasks/scripts for i need it for vsCode.

Reputable tech review sites claim this mouse can be used as a wired USB mouse in addition to being wireless. That is a lie.This was the main reason I bought the mouse: versatility. I needed an excellent ergonomic mouse with plenty of practical functionality and a really good scroll wheel. It should work wired and then wireless whenever I need it.Well, I just received the mouse and cannot use it for my primary purpose - as a wired USB mouse. I am very disappointed becaise that was the whole point in investing this much money in a mouse I can use anywhere. For $99, it should have this functionality!Deducting 2 stars for this disappontment & lack of basic functionality in an advanced mouse.
There is a Mac version of this mouse but this is not it.  The Mac version is the same price and you can find it on Amazon.

Seemed like a great mouse in the pictures description. I game lightly and use the mouse for productivity, thus I wanted wireless and long battery life. Everything seems great on it and the scroll wheel was awesome! Unfortunately I like to be able to control my mouse with my fingertips for high accuracy tasks and the ergonomics made that really hard with the fact that the click buttons were not attached to the complete plastic housing (i tend to click far back.) Works ok with my upright work, but not my reclined which is more than 3/4 of my time. great mouse, just not for me. Also Please make the forward back buttons larger! My G700 will still keep on kicking with its horrible battery life.

I had to buy a new mouse since the one I had at my employer that I left I obvisouly couldn't take. Well, I really like this one much better and would reccomend anyone to buy this who is looking for a great comfort ergo mouse.

I have a MX Master 2S which I use at my office.  When COVID hit, I strated working from home with an old mouse I had at home. It did the job fine but it recently broke, so I decided to upgrade to an MX Master 3 for my home office.This mouse is better than the 2S in many ways.1. The mouse's scroll wheel works better than it did on the 2s. The 2s had some issues in some situations, like with Google Maps, where it would either zoom in way too much at once, or not enough, the 3 seems to have fixed that.2. The continuous scroll on the mouse is MUCH quieter than on the 2s.  The 2s has a loud "click" when it starts and stops when used in the "bumpy" mode and not the smooth scrolling mode.3. The back and forward buttons are much better placed.  On the 2s they were so far back they were unusable for me.  I would still prefer them a bit more forward on the 3, but I have big hands.4. USB-C charging means I don't need a micro USB wire on my desk. The same wire now charges my phone, keyboard, or mouse.This mouse does have some weight to it, so it might not be the best choice for FPS gamers or people who need something super fast and accurate.  I play games on my PC, but nothing that demands that kind of speed so it works fine for me.I considered the 2S the best mouse on the market when I got it, and the 3 has outdone it.  I think this is a no brainer for anyone willing to spend the money for a good mouse.
Everything working perfectly, absolutly satisfied with my purchuse. 5 Stars
Not a good experience, there are scratches on the back and signs of use, although these do not affect the use, but the mentality will be very bad!

This is an absolutely lovely mouse; glides smoothly over my desk, feels great to the hand, and it adds a number of really useful tricks and window management goodies. It would be my favorite mouse ever if only I could figure out how to make it stop disconnecting and stuttering. Maybe this is a bad unit, because it doesn't play nicely with either my Windows 10 laptop or my Macbook Pro, but I'm just not going to spend any more time debugging something as elementary as a mouse in the year 2020. Returned.

I have had $100 mice and $20 mice. What I was looking for was that side scroll wheel. Turns out it can't be used to scroll pages up and down (I did assign the up and down arrows to it but it's too slow). What I didn't take into consideration were the amazingly sweet buttons and the free spin top scroll wheel. This thing is a joy to use and feels very well made and thought out. I even use it on Warthunder with no issues. It has a great fit for my hand, feels good, it's awesome. If I could use the side scroll for webpages it would be perfect.  I love this thing.

Such a wonderful device plagued by horrible Logi Options Software issues. When connecting the mouse through Bluetooth you are not able to change the settings of the mouse and most of the features do not work. So if you are ok with not using your Bluetooth feature and only use USB connection then it should be fine. Though, Bluetooth connectivity is the most attractive feature of this device as it allows you to switch between devices easily. Logi Tech's customer service is horrible and provided no help. Their window's version of the software has no issues. This problem is only for newer macOS.

I am a huge Logitech fanboy, I've had a marathon mouse that's been going strong for like 7 years, I only buy their keyboards, and I had an earlier version of this MX that—to this day I cannot figure out how but—I "lost" it, even though I never intentionally moved it from my desk. It just evaporated somewhere in my house.
Anyways, I got this MX 3 and love it, I have relatively big hands (span a 10th on piano) and always cramp up using smaller mouses. This one is fine. Feels solid quality, which feels good. Lots of buttons and it looks nice.BUT. And I have no idea how else to explain this, BUT. I cannot stop knocking it off the desk. This has never happened with any other mouse, wired or otherwise, but it's happened THREE times now (I'm writing this out of sheer frustration right after the third time) where I will reach over from the keyboard to the mouse and my fingers will catch it and straight up launch it off the desk, so this hundred dollar mouse just crashes to the floor and gets all scratched up and probably damaged inside. I have the same general setup and mousepad arrangement that I've had for two decades of computing. I don't know if it's just that it's a minuscule amount taller than other mice that I'm used to and my fingers are catching just so—but I feel like I have pretty good kinesthetics (I can play all my instruments blindfolded, if that means anything) and I've had it for 3 months or so now, so I should've adjusted by now. I'm pretty sure I'm going to break it because this keeps happening, and I don't want to put up a janky guardrail on my desk like I'm bad at bowling.Anyways, that's 100% user fault, so no slamming the product here. But I'm pretty sure mine is haunted by a suicidal ghost.
The scrolling wheel design is revolutionary! Can't go back to regular mouses.

I bought this with the MX Keys. We have a Mac mini and a perfectly stable ASUS Prime Deluxe II PC build for composing music. The keyboard switches between both computers great, feels good and the modifier keys are cool. The mouse is not. Through Bluetooth, the mouse is not nearly as responsive as through the wireless receiver. Secondly on the PC, the software routinely geeks out and changes DPI/navigation resolution and hangs - with the receiver 18” away line of sight. I believe this is because unlike other wireless Logitech mouses I have, this one does not save the settings internally, and must work through the software for everything in real-time. This makes sense if you are switching computer platforms on the fly, but it often gives you very poor performance when you least expect it and is not dependable. My wife is content using it to surf the web on a Mac. Otherwise it’s a big waste of money on performance for people doing media-based film/music production. You’ll run into random lag and navigation problems while your only using 10% cpu. It requires a restart to reset the software and before you run into this without expecting it - it does NOT work wired. It only charges wired. SmhNeat idea, poorly executed.

MX Master 3 is an impressive mouse. Functional, precise, ergonomic, and well built. MagSpeed scrolling is actually great. Battery life is excellent.Overall, it's one of the best mouses on the market.Four stars just for the cost. Despite being an excellent device, it's not worth the $100 price tag.

I use this in an apt that I share with two other people.  Other times I go to work I would like to bring this to the office. For some reason many of the iterations of the MX series have improved some aspects but have ignored this one. I as well as many others would want a mouse that has a more muted click sound I know I'm clicking it when I press it, there's no need to have such a loud click sound when I'm clicking at night when roommates are sleeping or when I'm the rogue emloyee at my company who has the loudest mouse clicking away.  It really serves no purpose to have such a loud click mechanism.  To mute it and dampen the sound would be amazing because when you're clicking away in an apt, it really echos throughout.  If I have someone over and they are sleeping, I can't work in the same room because the clicking is so loud. No other mouse clicks as loud as this one. Why don't you take it down several notches and dampen the sound.

Let me just say this, the mouse is extremely nice. It feels incredible in the hand and I don't know how else to say it than the mouse feels "luxurious".  It also works flawlessly on my glass desktop which I've never had a mouse do up to this point.  I opted for this over the Master 2S primarily because of the USB-C charging, but the magnetic adaptive scroll wheel is also very nice.So, why 1 star?  Pretty simple.  The only way to switch between multiple devices without using the Flow software is a button ON THE BOTTOM OF THE MOUSE.  Said button is also the only location for visual feedback of which device the mouse is connected to.  Somehow my $30 Triathlon is better than this $100 mouse in this regard which is ridiculous.  Even more ridiculous is the fact that moving this functionality to another button is currently IMPOSSIBLE in the software, despite every button seemingly being able to be any function on the computer or mouse, this is the one exception and it's incredibly frustrating.  I could excuse this on a less expensive mouse (like the Triathlon) but on what is more or less the pinnacle of Logitech's mouse line I expect better.  Had I known of this limitation I probably wouldn't have bought it and am debating sending it back.In addition to that major flaw, one reason I wanted this mouse was the horizontal scroll wheel.  It works as advertised, but I find the speed/acceleration much faster than expected, even at its lowest setting in the Options software.  Also, this wheel is smooth scroll only which I suppose is good for things like zooming, but it would have been nice for a ratcheted option for things like scrolling Excel cell by cell, or clicking through tabs in the browser.  This is a minor annoyance, but compounded with the major flaw and the fact that this mouse is hideously expensive, I have to give it a rare (for me) 1-star review.

I bought this to replace my G700, has been perfect for the office. Buttons are solid and feel like quality. The programming software makes it easy to set shortcuts like Copy and Paste, something I spend most of the day doing.
Amazing, don’t purchase any other mouse but this one.

Good: Just about everything. The ergonomics are much better than I'd thought at first view. Hand/wrist position is perfect; I'm using a mouse pad with built-in wrist rest but I suspect the latter isn't necessary with this mouse. Tracking is smooth and precise on every surface I've tried it on, including my denim-clad leg. Button action is very light, but your hand position is such that you're unlikely to click accidentally. Selector button on the underside lets you switch between three different receivers, which works well once you figure out how to pair it with a new receiver (see below.) Haven't used it long enough to verify battery life, but four days of intensive use hasn't fazed it. USB-C charging might put some people off but it comes with its own cable, and USB-C enables rapid charging. After four days of several-hours-daily use, I can't think of anything bad to say about this mouse. Except...Bad: I bought this along with Logi's MX Keys keyboard, so I needed to pair both with both receivers. The getting-started sticker on the mouse's underside wasn't quite clear on the pairing process, so I looked it up on Logi's website. No problem: power up the mouse, press the "connect" button, plug in the receiver, and done. I flip the mouse over, switch it on, receiver select "1" starts flashing as it's supposed to, I press the...wait a minute, there's no "connect" button. Online manual clearly shows it between the power switch and the sensor. Nope. So about 20 minutes of research and fumbling later, I discover that it's necessary to download and install 200 meg of Logitech bloatware, click through multiple screens of features of the device I've already paired, and pleas to open an account (nope) and send my every click to Logi for analytics (double nope,) and then figure out how to get to the pairing screen. Once I found that, the pairing was almost effortless. My point, however, is that none of this should have been necessary. It's a MOUSE, people, it should be plug-and-play to at least get it working before considering enhancements. At the very least you shouldn't have to run an online gauntlet to be able to use what is now a fundamental peripheral. Would have sucked if I hadn't had internet access at the time. Also...Ugly: The required pairing software doesn't work on Linux, which means I had to install said bloatware on my work machine and pair up both receivers there. It wasn't a problem, but could easily have become one if the system admins took note.Bottom line: The MX Master 3 lives up to its reputation. This replaced an older Logi mouse, and I don't miss the old one a bit. Five stars, minus one because the apparently deliberate move to force users to install an app just to make the device usable - and a Windows-only app at that - annoyed me just enough to take back that fifth star.
is a good mouse ...but less than year stop working don't know why ...I'm not a hard user?not charging also!!!!

A clear scam, I paid for a brand new one yet got sent a used one, bottom plates are scratched and even one is slightly dented.  Didn't bother to return since it works as expected but this is false advertising.Others great mouse.

Once you start using it you will feel the difference on how smooth it is compared to other mice. It has been 2 weeks since I received it and the battery is still going on, using it more than 8 hours per day.

Avid Mac user and had been eyeing the Magic Mouse 2 until a friend recommenced this mouse to me. I love the Mac trackpad so much I don't even mind designing in 3D CAD software with it, but this mouse has been a very pleasant surprise. The Mac's trackpad gestures are a big reason why I didn't want to leave the Apple ecosystem for a mouse, but this mouse has built in capabilities that allow you to mimic those gestures! Outside of that great feature the mouse is incredibly programable for a bunch of different applications such as the whole Adobe Creative Cloud suite and even 3D modeling software such as Rhino or Revit!

This mouse has fantastic ergonomics and I love the weight.  I rally like the side scroll wheel and the forward/back buttons are placed pretty well.  I have noticed that the receiver needs to be fairly close or the response starts to lag.  This could potentially be an issue in competitive gaming, but not an issue for productivity really.  Not an issue at all if you are able to have the mouse about 2-feet or less from the receiver.I really like that this can be paired with more than one receiver and is the reason I purchased this mouse.  That feature works perfectly.  The flow technology works reasonably well.  There is slight lag when moving between computers, but I would not expect it to work the same as with two monitors on a single computer.

I have in the past used only apple magic track pads or mac itself. Felt that a traditional mouse would limit the gesture controls which are important for my workflow. Tried this mouse and have been impressed and I seem to have been discovering new ways to map gestures per app and for the whole OS and makes it so productive with minimal effort. Its a great purchase. The only con was I have never got the unifying receiver to work. It seems to be stuttering in the unifying mode while works smooth in bluetooth mode. The mouse supports three bluetooth devices so it is easy to switch and manage at home with multiple devices
Love love loveBuy it
Personalization of this mouse is too complex and annoying.Also, it is too heavyBut the material quality of it is good!
This mouse is the worst. This $100 mouse lags, jitters, stutters, even freezes. Worse than $10 mouse. I am a professional video editor and this is totally unacceptable. I am returning this.

I've been using Logitech mice ever since the company started pretty much. After all those crappy non-gaming mice that Microsoft were putting out back in the 90's, somebody had to step up! But if your old school like me, then you remember Logitech's logo back in the day. Turns out the company rebranded themselves to "Logi", following fears, that their company was considered a dinosaur by young folk. The re-branding's intention, is to make themselves seem hip as ever.How many remember the Logitech MX1000 wireless laser gaming mouse? Over 15-years ago Logitech came out with that mouse, captured my heart forever. Used it for 7-years until the lithium battery died for good. Then I bought my first "G" mouse, the G700, back when the mice still were remanescent of the MX1000, just with added features and performance. Then the mice went total futuristic and overkill, when the G502 and G9 series came out lol.The Logitech MX Master 3 Advanced, is literally one of the best mice out there. It still amazes me to this day, just how many features that they can pack, into a small space. The weight feels about the same as the old MX1000 and G700, so if you've used those mice before, then you will be used to it. The Master series has actually been around for several years now, and this is the 3rd generation mouse.Because of the weight, this mouse does not glide over my cloth Hcman mouse pad, as easily as my Razer Deathadder Elite wired gaming mouse. However, the mouse pad was designed to allow a mouse tracking sensor, to have 100% precision in every micro-inch of movement. Wireless mice will glide easier over a plastic based mouse pad, however, the mouse will probably be less precise if you use one. So stick with a micro-fiber cloth mouse pad if you can.This is a 7-button mouse, and as expected, there are many functions. Left Click, Middle Click, Right Click, Vertical Scroll, Forward Click, Backward Click, Productivity Button, Horizontal Scroll. Scroll Mode button adjusts the scroll wheel mode, clicky or smooth. On the bottom of the mouse is the ON/OFF switch, as well as the Bluetooth mode selector, and of course, the DARK FIELD sensor, that can track on literally everything, including your ham sandwich.I bought this, so I would have a quality wireless mouse, for my tablet computer. Because it can be programmed for more then just 1-device at a time, I can also use this with my notebook computer. Its important to note however, Logitech software only works on Windows or MAC, there is no software support for Android. This mouse works perfectly with an Android tablet however, using Android standard drivers and functionality, built into the OS.As soon as I turned the mouse on, the #1 mode began flashing. I searched for Bluetooth devices on my tablet, and immediately the mouse was discovered, and paired quickly. Reception is excellent, the cursor moved almost as smoothly as my wired Razer Dethadder Elite gaming mouse. If your somebody who does photoshop, or Adobe Premiere for production and editing work, you will love this mouse, plenty of sensitivity to get the job done.Browsing the internet performance is very good as well. Other then the standard vertical scroll wheel that all modern mice have these days, I found myself also enjoying, the horizontal scroll wheel, which allowed me to scroll the pages left/right. This makes browsing the internet on a tablet much easier, and quicker. If you've been using your touch screen before, this mouse is going to be quite the upgrade for you!Gaming performance is very good for a mouse that isn't technically rated to be meant for gaming. Unless your a competitive gamer, trying to reach the top ranks in COD, Battlefied, Fortnite, PubG, you don't need no 144 hertz G9! These MX Master 3 mice have more precision then the MX1000 had, its plenty for gaming IMO, and I did not have any problems.I also do photoshop and video editing, but not professionally, and I find this mouse very easy to use. The ergonomics of this mouse are top notch, best I've seen! I find this mouse very comfortable to use. The mouse clicks are fairly strong, which provides tactile feedback. And the forward and back buttons, are thankfully not mushy like previous models, also very tactile. If you don't like loud mice, you might want to stay away, tactile feedback, means there is gonna be click noise.Logitech seems to only have this mouse in either Graphite, or Mid-Grey. It would be nice if they came out with an pure Black version, as well as a Blue, and premium Red version. But like I said, they are catering to production artists more with this mouse then gamers. Still, Logitech should offer more custom options, it would get them more sales IMO.If you don't want your mouse to look like a space ship however, and your not a super competitive gamer, you can avoid the G502 and the G9, and just go with the MX Master 3. In my opinion, its a fully featured mouse, with excellent precise control from the Dark Field sensor, excellent customisability of buttons through the driver software, and excellent ergonomics. Very well made mouse, and I am going to have to give it a solid 5 out of 5 stars!

Looking for a mouse and can't decide. Just get this!I've a habit of over-researching things before I buy and I spent almost 2 months lookong for a right mouse. Pretty much all sources point to this mouse and now I know why.Pros:- Ergonomic, sits nicely in my large hands- great battery life- the horizontal scroll and infinite vertical scroll are a big help- USB C charging. Need I say more?- Connects via unifying receiver so I don't need additional ports occupied.Cons:- Haven't found any

A firmware update prompted by the Logitech Options software bricked the mouse today. It is unusable and Logitech will not respond to a ticket opened on their website or call back after using that option in their telephone support queue.Logitech did eventually respond (over 3 weeks later) and provided a new firmware tool that fixed the issue.

My MX Master is still working fine. I just wanted to test these new ones and they are amazing.The scroll feels a little weird at first but you'll get used to it. It's a little slimmer and lighter compared to MX Master 1, which makes it more ergonomic and comfortable.

I do mainly computer work such as 3D design and animation so I need a reliable and accurate mouse. I got tired of using all these popular "gaming" mice because something keeps wearing out: a button, the wheel, the sensitivity, etc.I decided to get something more professional and higher quality. This seemed like a good candidate so I gave it a try. So far I love everything about the mouse except for the fact that it cannot be used wired. You MUST use the dongle that comes with it to transmit and receive signal. You can use it while it is plugged in but it only charges the mouse, not transmit data.The problem with this is the dongle isn't accurate and secure. It randomly skips or loses signal all too often. The dongle is on my desk and about 2-3 feet from the mouse with nothing in between. It's such a pain to do work and not have the mouse do what you want it to. I was hoping to be able to use the mouse directly plugged into the computer to fix this issue but I can't.I will try a few more weeks before I decide to go for a wired mouse.
It's the most comfortable mouse I've ever used for work.I have the Master MX2 as well, and this is a very welcome upgrade.Scrolling through huge excel spreadsheets is a breeze.
hello , i purchased this mouse and really extremely happy with it, but for some reason i lost my USB receiver of this mouse how can i solve this issue ? i need help

As a mouse itself, i don't have any complaints. It is ergonomically good to hold, the scroll wheel is amazing to use. All the buttons including the thumb wheel can be customized. The problem i have is, all these customization requires the software to be installed in every laptop we would use. I have customized the buttons in my personal computer, but they don't work in my office laptop and i cannot install the software in my office laptop. One more negative, it doesn't have a slot to store the Logitech unifying receiver (USB dongle), every other mouse i have used in recent years have this slot and i find it very useful.

After extensive research I purchased this mouse as it came with the claim that is was highly ergonomic. However, this is without a doubt the least ergonomic mouse I have ever tried. I don't know where to begin with all the things that are wrong with it.First, the forward and back buttons on the thumb are way too small. If you want to go forward, you have to contort your thumb in a very unpleasant fashion to click on it. For the back button, unless your knuckle is sitting right below the button, you will have the same issue.As for the mouse, I want it fit my hand like a glove. I should be able to comfortably rest my hand on it. This is not at all possible with this mouse. My entire hand is in a tented position with my index finger at an odd angle spinning the wheel. And I push the mouse with the other fingers instead of my palm.No matter how you look at it, every part of your hand and wrist is going to hurt.NOTE: I gave this 1 star for the product and NOT the seller. I had no problem with the seller and after carefully reviewing the description they have, nowhere do they claim this mouse is ergonomic (with good reason).

This "Logitech MX Master 3 Advanced Wireless Mouse" provides an nice feature set and is solidly built and ergonomically shaped.  Admittedly I rarely if ever use the extra features like the thumbwheel and side buttons, so I make no claims as to the excellence or lack thereof for those functions. I just like the shape of the device as a whole, find it comfortable to use, and the only functions I really care about (button 1, button 2, and center scroll wheel) all perform flawlessly. But after all is said and done, it's horribly expensive for a mouse not made entirely  out of platinum, and I would not buy it nor any mouse at the current list price (99 bux). The less than stellar rating is entirely due to the price.
Awesome mouse

I can't believe what I've been doing with my life without this mouse, I'm a developer who uses the computer at least 8 hours a day and this mouse is the most comfortable mouse I have ever used. It is super ergonomic (which is the reason I switched from the magic mouse). And has many options that make your life easier. Best mouse for MacOS and Windows.The only thing that I could have changed was to include a compartment for the USB receiver in the mouse.
good touch feeling

I’m a graphic designer and the laptop track pad was killing my carpel tunnel! Since day 1 I felt the difference with this device. It makes my hand rest while working, and is very nice to use. It moves smoothly and has several features to make the clicks more practical.

I bought it specifically for the scroll wheel, and it didn't disappoint.  The button near the scroll wheel lets you turn off the clicky steps so it's very smooth.  It has weight, so you can fling it to jump very far.  I wasn't sure what I would think about the thumb rest, but it doesn't annoy me.  I wish the whole thing was a bit lighter, and picking it up requires retraining and effort to use the ribbed texture instead of the underside lip.
Very good mouse for smooth scrolling on mac and windows

I had the first gen with still works perfectly after about 6 years and it was time to get a new one seriously this is the BEST mouse you can get the new model battery lasts so long and it’s really confortable.
Bought it to wfh. Works well on my mac.

Im coming from the original MX Master 1st Gen Mouse so for me this is a massive jump.The design is much sleeker and fits better with the hand. The new scroll wheel is far more pleasant and seamless to use than before. This mouse builds on the strengths of its predecessors to make a much more refined product.Caveats:1) The unifying receiver is still using USB-A as the input method. I wouldve preferred it to be USB-C so I dont have to use an adapter on devices that dont have USB-A anymore.2) The charging cable is also USB-C to USB-A ( this part going into your device which you use to charge the mouse) . Same issues as relayed in Caveat 1.Excluding the caveats, overall this is a fantastic evolution of the MX Master series and Im thoroughly satisfied with my purchase. I just hope Logitech will opt to go all in with the USB-C implementation in the future.
Not for gaming. Awesome mouse for working!
Stop looking this is the mouse

The MX Master series mouse is one of my favorite mice series. I switched from the MX Master 1 to the MX Master 3. The jump to the 3 was perfect. I really like the vertical scroll on the mouse wheel the material when scrolling feels solid and the thumb scroll button is a must for me especially when reading documents and websites. I remapped the additional buttons to open my more common applications which increases productivity for various tasks.

This device has decent mechanics (scroll wheel, lasers, functionality) but its designed by an idiot. NOT ERGONOMIC. Its like a torture device. The fewer features there are on the profile, the more comfortable and ergonomic the mouse will be.
I can just tell that the Logitech MX Anywhere 2S, although a smaller mouse is BETTER ergonomically than this one, because you arent forcing your arm\forearm\elbow in a stupid position to use it. The mouse should conform to your hand not the other way around.Its obviously usable. But this is not something you wont to use day in and out for years.Bring back the MX Revolution.

I was looking for a Logitech mouse that was wireless, had decent battery life, and had all sorts of buttons and programmable options.  This fit the bill!  I use it daily at work, it fits my hand well, and does everything I ask it to do.  Great product!
This is an incredible product. I do however see some evidence of use on the one I received from this seller

I've had this mouse for 6 months now and I would highly recommend it! I bought mine from a computer store but I wanted to leave a review here because I love this product so much. I was previously using the apple magic mouse but was having wrist pain after spending hours at my computer for work. With the MX 3 I haven't had any wrist pain (though sometimes my fingers need a stretch from clenching it tightly for a long period).My two favorite features are the horizontal scroll wheel and the multi computer pairing (up to 3 computers). It is SO convenient to be able to switch from my laptop to my desktop with the touch of a button (on the bottom of the mouse). It's also a breeze bringing it into the office because of the bluetooth USB that's included. Plug in the USB to the computer and your mouse is good to go on another machine!The battery life is impressive. I've definitely gone at least two weeks without charging it. Unlike Apple's magic mouse -- the charging port is in the front of the mouse so you are able to continue to use the mouse while it's charging. It charges with a USB-C cable.Also the mouse has several different buttons that are customizable to different applications you use. It's a genius feature but I've been too lazy to set it up.I spent more than I thought I ever thought I would on a mouse but it's totally worth it -- especially if you work at a computer for 8+ hours/day.
I ordered this mouse cos my old one makes noise on clicks. This is no different, Everything else is good once paired with logitech options.

The charging cord appears to be proprietary. Do not misplace it, leave it in a hotel, on an airplane, in couch cushions or let the dog eat it. Do not throw it the drawer with the hundreds of cords. I would advise you  to zip tie it to your computer. That said, nice mouse. The scroll feature does not always work on chrome browser when trying to change tabs.
I use with my MacBook Pro 16” with Bluetooth. Fits my hand perfectly

while searching for a keyboard.  I bought the Logitech Ergo K860 keyboard and needed a mouse to go with it and bought the MX Master 3.  The keyboard is great...no complaints, but the mouse is awesome!  I had no idea I needed a mouse like this.  I often look at huge spreadsheets and diagrams and I have never had a mouse with horizontal scroll or a normal scroll that is as fast as this.  This is going to help my efficiency for sure and the comfort of the new keyboard and mouse will help me work longer without getting tired.  Great Combo!  Logitech Ergo K860 and MX Master 3 mouse!

I like Logitech mice which I use with my Mac through a Bluetooth connection.  My previous mouse was a Logitech MX Anywhere 2S.  While I was very happy with this mouse, its vertical scrolling, using its mouse wheel, left much to be desired, especially when I tries to use it with any of my web browsers (e.g., Google Chrome) or Microsoft Excel.  My new Logitech MX Master 3, although bulkier, offers me better functionality especially with vertical scrolling.  This purchase met my expectations.

The ergonomics of this mouse are terrible. The right edge is smooth and slope-y, and doesn't give you a good surface to grip. It, therefore, makes it difficult to move the mouse left/right without feeling like the mouse will just slip out of your hand (even though it won't). It's very distracting when using it.As for Logitech Flow, well, they have more than a few kinks to iron out in their software. "Flow"ing from my Windows laptop to Mac is either slow (takes a minute for the destination laptop to pick up the mouse signal) or just doesn't happen (which is when I switch the mouse off and use the toggle switches on the bottom to connect to the desired laptop). Both scenarios are frustrating.After disabling Flow altogether, some issues persist. There are still times when the Mac won't pick up the mouse (this happens with the MxKeys keyboard as well) and I need to pair the mouse/keyboard again with the laptop. This should not be happening with $100 products.I'm happy to deal with this problem for the keyboard- the key quality is great, the backlight is very useful- but with the mouse, I would've just preferred to buy a regular old Bluetooth mouse and moved the dongle over to the laptop I used.In short, this mouse is not worth it.

We needed an extra mouse for the office.  Was using a Logitech Performance to MX 3.  The Logitech Performance mouse was just fine.  A very good mouse.  However, I do have the following comments with this mouse.1.  More comfortable2.  Nicer texture3.  Scroll wheels are awesome.  Best I have ever used4.  Battery life.  Awesome.  No charging station so one less item on my desk.I am happy that I purchased this mouse.  Makes my life a little easier.

Look at the support community at Logitech for this mouse. You'll see a consistent problem with the scroll wheel and less often the mouse pointer itself just quitting working for a few seconds.I had the problems.  Support was only via email, so it took days to get the several round trips to try and resolve. They finally suggested updating the USB and Bluetooth drivers on the PC.  That fixed most, but not all, of the problems.  Logitech opted to send me a new mouse. Same problems with it.I am baffled that Logitech's mouse doesn't work with drivers on a laptop that is less than 2 years old.  What about backwards compatibility?Other than the above, the mouse (when working) is great!PROS: - Great feel in the hand. - Scroll function (that accelerates for faster scrolls as you spin the control) is super for scrolling through large datasets. - Ability to use the mouse in both Bluetooth and with the Logitech dongle is a great feature. - Ability to use the mouse with 3 separate systems is great! (Small button on the bottom to select.) - USB-C charging is nice, and the battery is decent.  (Not as good as the alkaline mice I've had in the past, but much better than the chargeable mouse I replaced - I am a heavy user and have to charge every 4-5 days. - New management software allows for much more customization (even by program), albeit it's not as intuitive as one would like.  Took some trial and error to change things.CONS: - See failure discussion above. - No user-accessible battery compartment. So when that rechargeable battery goes (typically by not holding a charge very long), I'll be forced to buy a new mouse or take my screwdriver to it. - Logitech support quality is low. Ability to identify a solution to a common problem (just look at the support community) isn't there, and the email process is way too slow.In short, I recommend this mouse IF you are willing to immediately return it if it doesn't work. Don't bother with Logitech support.
Wow is the only word i can say. Its fast and works better than the apple one.

Mouse is very accurate but after the last Windows 10 update the Logitech Options software just comes up with a blank window. You can't set any options. Tried all their solutions, uninstalling, deleting files, reinstalling. nothing.I'm not the only one with this problem. Even worse, installing the Options software also took over all my keyboard options and now I can't set any keys on that either. I don't recommend getting anything from Logitech that installs their new Options software. Too bad. A lot of money for something that doesn't work.  Mouse itself is nice so it gets two stars.
I like the design to help me remember to not lay my hand on the desk.  Precise and many features.
No surprises.Very good mouse as all its predecessors.

This would be a 5 star review as I love the mouse.  I have an issue though where when I place my finger on the scroll wheel it clicks.  Whenever I actually press the scroll wheel for middle click it clicks twice.  This does not affect performance of the mouse itself but I paid a premium for it because I wanted better quality and it should not be happening.  Logitech support will not help me and after sending them a video with the click being clearly audible they told me they don't see a problem, and I cannot crack it open to see whats going on inside as that will void the warranty.  Hopefully if you purchase this thing you will have better luck than I did but if you have to deal with Logitech support, well I wish you the best.
The Speed scroll is sweet and the mouse feels like quality in hand!

Terrible technical support!  Nice mouse but software for it sucks! Options app does not seem to support something as simple as assigning button to launchpad on MacBook ProSoftware is clearly out of date for MACOS 10.15.4! Very disappointed with software and non existent support from Logitech.  Definitely would not recommend if you workstation is a MAC.
Blue tooth function is not good, in pairs with the device all the time.
all features you want are in one device. Worth every dollar I spent. Every button is customizable and the software is very easy to use.
Hands down, I LOVE this mouse. I work in the visualization field and upgraded my Razor Oroborus to this and I am never looking back.

Gonna need a software update on the scroll wheel. The mouse if comfortable and very functional for workflow; however, the scroll wheel is not accurate at all. If you search reviews on forums this is a common issue. Fix it Logitech...

This mouse is amazing. I use it with several screens, which were super easy to set up with the guide they provide online. Fully customizable buttons, though they take some getting used to with how I have to move my thumb: mostly because I haven't used my thumb for things like this before.It's only 4 stars because while it works perfect it was advertised as new, but when I inspected it the bottom gliding pads were clearly scuffed and used, even a small scratch near one of the logos underneath, and yes that was before I used it.

Bottom line up, I ended up initiating return after about 2 hours of use/trial.CONS:1. Scroll Wheel: The biggest issue with this mouse is the scrolling, scrolling is VERY inconsistent.  When you are scrolling up and down with the scroll wheel, it does not move at a smooth or constant rate. If you are used to trackpad or magic mouse, you probably know what I mean.2. Gesture button: The location of this gesture button is not optimal.  I attached the pictures but naturally, your finger will rest much higher than where the gesture button is actually located and it's really hard to use the whole gestures.  My main productivity involves around all these gestures.  I'm currently running a dual monitor setup with multiple desktop spaces per screen, and having easy access to mission control and full desktop scrolling is crucial for me.  This unnatural placement of the gesture button makes these functions really hard.3.  ** EDIT: LOGITECH commented saying there is a way to setup with a single dongle. Please discard this** USB dongle:  This one is not a deal-breaker BUT... it's still a CON for me.  So, I purchased this mouse as a set with the MX Keys.  I initially thought since these two devices are in the same product line, I could just get away with using a single USB dongle.  But until I had both of the dongles plugged in, I was not able to use both devices.  So, having to use two dongles pretty much fills up all my port and I need to get an additional hub in order to compensate for lack of USB space.  If I were to use a magic mouse, magic trackpad, and full size magic keyboard, I wouldn't even need a single port because they all run on bluetooth.  Sacrificing one USB port is ok, two is just not optimal.After realizing all these flaws within an hour or so of use, I just had to initiate return because using the MX Keys and MX Master 3 will not increase any of my productivity.PROS:Since I did a fair amount of complaining, here are some plus.1. Software:  Logitech software is pretty amazing when it comes to customization.  You are able to inverse the trackwheel scrolling directions on mac without affecting the natural track scrolling directions of the trackpad or the OS settings itself.  This is actually a huge plus since there are other manufacture mice (razer) that do not let you do this and when you inverse the mouse directions on the macOS settings itself, you are inversing trackpad scrolling as well.  Logitech has an override for the trackwheel scrolling direction, and it's really awesome.  Also, you can map A LOT of different gestures/functions to additional buttons on the mouse, and have options to map buttons differently according to the app you are using.2. Mouse Track:  Tracking on the mouse is really awesome, no signs of an intermittent drop in connections, and feels almost like using a wired mouse.

I've been using Logitech mice for decades, but I've also used each MX Master mouse (versions one and two).  I purchased the MX Master 3 a few weeks ago and it's far and away the best mouse I've ever used.  Feels great, works great... It's just perfect for my use case.It charges over USB-C, and comes with a USB-C to USB-A cable to charge, but the Logitech Unifying Receiver is still USB-A, so if you're a MacBook user, take note.  But since it also has built-in Bluetooth, you can connect to any Bluetooth-enabled computer, so there's really no worry.  Also works great with the new iPadOS that supports mouse input.

I have been using the G502 wired version for a couple years. Earlier today I picked up the new Logitech Keys and since Logitech Flow is definitely a great feature to have, I picked up the new MX Master 3 mouse as well. I'm not sure why people have been raving the scrolling wheel on this mouse?!?! The technology has been used on pretty much all Logitech G mouses for quite sometime now. Not only that, if you have been using something like the G502 (mine is 4-5 yrs old and wired which is being sold for less than $50), this mouse is nowhere close. The scrolling wheel is heavy, the sensor is just not as precise as the G502. Anyhow, very premium packaging. Finish is alright. Overall, it still is a great upgrade for anyone coming from standard mouse that came with your desktop. If you have been using G series mouse from Logitech and temping to get it with your MX Keys, I would just skip it for now and save the money. As of right now, I'm heavily consider the wireless G502 but that also means I'm loosing Logitech Flow feature.

Update: I'm having a major issue with this mouse where every few minutes or so the polling rate drops drastically and it becomes very unresponsive for 5-10 seconds. It sounds minor, but makes it really tedious to use as I'm constantly having to stop what I'm doing.Pros:Overall the MX3 feels great in your hand (no double entendre's here) and is generally wonderful to use. It has a nice weight that makes if feel very sturdy without hindering movement. The battery life is also quite nice, though we'll see how that ages. The gesture button is also a bit strange, but an interesting idea. I'm just not sure how much mileage I'll end up getting out of it.Cons:I'm really not a fan of the scroll wheel. It's very quiet which is nice, but actually using it to scroll is more painful than even the cheapest mice I've used. Even in locked mode it will start free-wheeling if you scroll fast enough, which is strange considering it also has an unlocked mode that functions the same. It also starts to feel really weird to use in the middle ranges and it leads to this weird feeling where you can't really accurately predict how far you're going to scroll down.  I also find myself really missing the ability to switch DPI profiles easily (like with the G903) when I hop into a game.
This thing is awesome. Buttons are in better locations compared to its predecessor MX Master 2. Battery life is maybe a week or two after using for about 10-12 hours a day.

I've had mx master since it's first generation. amazing mouse, responsive, works virtually on any surface. battery life is great as well. programmable functions - series 3 has application specific profiles that come in handy too

I am using this mouse in combination with MX3 keyboard via a single dongle.  It works, most of the time.  I experience "lag jumps" constantly on the mouse (not the keyboard).  Logi forums are full of reports of the same issue without a resolution so I am not sure how people are ok with this and give it such a high rating.  Forget about using it while gaming.  The design of the device is not that ideal either.  The mouse fits well into my hand; however, I wish it was heavier for a more solid tracking feel.I will most likely return this product, as $100 dollar price is not worth the mediocre tracking issues.  I can try again when it is ready for primetime.

It is amazing that this new release of the MX Master does not work reliably with Mac.Each time it restarts the Mac does not connect automatically to it, and although the Mouse shows up in bluetooth preferences it still will not manually connect. The mouse needs to be removed from bluetooth and then manually reconnected.I have followed all Logitech's advice and restarted bluetooth and removed the plist file!I would have thought that Logitech could do a better job of something as basic as bluetooth connectivity. In fact the original MX Master which I still have is more reliable in connecting to bluetooth, whereas this one must have the prior connection deleted AND a new connection made before it works. The fact that Logitech has a special section on their website to report bluetooth connectivity problems perhaps tells you all that is needed about their confidence in their product. In 2020 bluetooth connectivity should not be difficult for anyone!!!Don't buy if you have a Mac and want reliable connectivity.

* The mouse stutters like hell over plain Bluetooth connection* Logitech Options is the only way to truely "Pair" the device after the initial Bluetooth connection (and requires a second pointing device in the meantime)* To fix stutter issues, disconnect the mouse from Bluetooth and connect another mouse, then plug in the dongle (called "Unifying receiver"), open Logitech Options and say "Connect Device through Unifying Reciever", then turn the device off then on again. You can now put away the other mouse and use this oneIf you bought this device because you wanted to free up a USB slot then I feel sorry for you. Simply put the mouse is nothing without the dongle, so you need the USB dongle plugged in. Otherwise the mouse will stutter so bad you will wish for something different. So yes, you can use one dongle to connect the keyboard and the mouse but you at least need the dongle. You cannot hardly use this over simple bluetooth.It is a good product with a nice design and feels good in the hands, but the connection issues are a little worrying for something that costs as much as this does. It's strictest competition is cheap, reliable USB dongle Keyboard and mouse combos that are plug and play so to have this not work over bluetooth and not work out of the box with the dongle surely means that this product will suffer in the general consumer market unless something is done to alleviate the connectivity issues.The stuttering is unbearable over bluetooth. Skip it and use the dongle. I was hoping to have 2 less things plugged into USB (mouse and keyboard) but now I just have one less USB connection (keyboard and mouse share) which really isn't that great of an improvement to be completely honest.Really anything in the with plug and play functionality is probably worth it. I like the ergo feel of this mouse and it has some cool features like the thumb wheel and gestures but it comes at the cost of being able to be set up out of the gate and for some reason requires a completely separate set of software acting as a middleman that completely blows my mind.For something in this price range you would really want it to be like 4.5 5 stars. Mouse and pointing technology has not matured past 20 years ago when I was using computers as a child. Turns out not much has changed it seems. So maybe turn your attention to something that will save you some money in the long run unless you will be using the daylights out of the sides croll and hotkeys feature.

I came to this from the original MX Mouse - which was still going strong, but my son dropped it and the back/forward buttons got jammed. I've had the original one since 2013 and it just refused to die of natural causes. :-)So when it broke I was actually excited to 'upgrade'.Bad move!Two reasons:a) Getting worse carpal tunnel symptoms with this mouse - the ergonomics are just not the same as the original mouseb) The metal in the mouse makes a super annoying sound whenever I click.I'll be using a Microsoft Keyboard/Mouse combo instead - with their ergonomic mouse. I use that at work already - but like to keep things different to avoid repetitive injury issues. Oh well, maybe the next iteration will be better.Unfortunately I have thrown away all the packaging otherwise would have returned the mouse. Will have to recycle. Same goes for the MXKeys keyboard too - it just sounds annoying with every key I type.
I'm still giving this a 5 star because I like it so much... there is one glaring problem to me, though. It really needs on-board storage for the USB dongle. I'm bound to lose that one day...

This is my 3rd mouse in 5 months. I started working from home 5 months ago and had a cheap $5 mouse I was using that was way too small and didn't even have a scroll wheel. I "upgraded" to a $20 mouse and that was a noticeable difference but the busier I got with work, the more I realized I needed something better.After 3 months of reading reviews, I decided to bite the bullet with the MX Master 3. I only wish I would have made the jump sooner. I have to scroll through large documentations all day long and the scroll wheel alone is worth the cost of upgrading. Everything feels smoother on my PC with the new mouse. Clicks are a breeze and the mouse feels great in my hands. I'm still learning some of the customized features and gestures. The back and forward buttons  easy to reach and use.If you work from home, need a mouse for office productivity and can afford it, go with this mouse.

For $100 you expect pretty good things in a mouse... this doesn't quite make it and doesn't function as advertised!This is pushed as working with the MX Keys and similar logitech keyboards to function across multiple devices.  These features simply do not work without installing (frankly awful) "Options" software on all devices (which isn't possible if you're trying to use this on remotely managed work devices).The mouse in particular has it's "device selection" or easy-switch located UNDER the mouse.  So, switching between devices requires two hands as you need to pick up the mouse, flip it upside-down, then pushing a recessed button (perhaps multiple times) to toggle between devices.
