Without this, this is just a heavy mouse with limited functionality to me. It is these types of limitations that make this mouse less ergonomic. Back to my Roccat.
The biggest thing I noticed was the change in the layout of the forward and back thumb buttons. They've improved the sensitivity and the battery life is unbelievable.

Finally stopped waiting for it to go on sale and bit the bullet for $99.  Replaced an MX Revolution - had bought 3 of them used since production stopped in 2007. Reviewer Name: Trust me, I'm not a hipster
Review: I got an office job for the first time in 7 years, and the first purchase I made was the Apple Magic Mouse. It's a sleek design, and the touch control is nice, but it leads to a very sore hand at the end of the day.This mouse is very comfortable, especially for someone with large hands. I do miss the touch control of the Magic Mouse, but this mouse makes up for it with comfort, build quality, and customizability. I do some video editing, and having all of the buttons is incredible. I set the left thumb button to Undo, the right thumb button to Blade, the bottom thumb button to Zoom with Scroll, and the small center button to Keyframe. Definitely speeds up the editing process to have access to some frequently used functions.I use this on a plastic faux wood desk top with no mouse pad and have never had issues with tracking after 4+ weeks.The scroll wheel unlocking seems gimmicky, but I actually like it. Line mode gives accurate scrolling, and free mode is nice to get to the bottom of a web page or document etc. Though when automatically switching from free mode to line mode while the wheel is turning it makes a slight buzzing sound. Might be annoying to some, or not suitable for all situations, but this automatic switching feature can be disabled to prevent that from happening.PROS:Very comfortable.Incredibly customizable. Buttons can be changed per app.The free scrolling is quite nice.It feels very premium.Very accurate.CONS:The scroll wheel makes a buzzing sound when switching from free scroll to line scroll while the wheel is turning.I basically recommend this to everyone in all situations, and will likely buy another one.
The best I have used and programmable is a big plus. Very responsive and can be used on glass. I tried it.
Comfortable shape fits the hand perfectly!

OMG where do I begin. MX Master 3 is the best mouse you can buy right now, provided you're not a gamer. I don't game on my computer so I can't speak for gaming with this mouse, but as fas as getting work done and other day-to-day usage, this mouse is perfect.Compared to the last gen Master 2S, this mouse has significantly improved on the scrolling wheel, which is a ton smoother and doesn't make that loud clacking sound when scrolling under ratchet model. The new wheel is an absolute joy to use, massively improving upon an already advanced component. Also, the button placement on the side is a lot better too. The back and forward buttons are comfortably located instead of being cramped behind the side scroll wheel, making them a lot easier to access. I find myself using these buttons a lot more often than before. Oh did I mention there are more options in the software Options than before? The customizations to this mouse is practically unlimited - I have customized every single button and has implemented app-specific shortcuts on over a dozen apps. I am able to do pretty much everything a lot faster on this mouse than on any other mouse. Caution: once you're used to it, there's no going back.Ergo-wise, I like the feel of the Master 3 better than 2S. The mouse is thinner overall (looks like it lost some weight), making it more comfy to hold. The mouse surface is covered in a softer skin-like rubber layer, which is more comfy than the harder plastic-y finish on 2S. Tracking is pretty much the same, meaning it's gonna be enough for any regular user with any high-res monitors. Build quality also feels better than the 2S.Overall, this is just a fantastic mouse. It's solidly build, carefully designed, and well executed. It's not cheap; but if you decide to invest in a good productivity mouse to improve your workflow, then look no further.

For being so super expensive mouse ($100), the magnetically controlled scroll wheel is buggy as hell. Knowing, that it's magnetically controlled and can be adjusted by software, itt still doesn't work right. I am trying to scroll 'UP', and many times the mouse doesn't sense I'm scrolling at all. If I go really slow, then it registers. Everything else works great, I just don't understand Logitech anymore. I really like how it feels and there is no issue with movement and speed, but the damn wheel is super annoying. I can't remember having such a bad experience, since the time when computer mice had a rolling ball and collected lint. I'm considering returning this mouse, it's unacceptable to have this sort of a problem on a $10 mouse, let alone $100. Magnetic or not.

I used the original MX Revolution for years, skipped the MX Performance due to the scroll wheel, picked up the MX Master 2S, and now it looks like I'm skipping this generation as well.Compared to the MX Master 2S:Pros:* USB C!  I was really excited for this, so I'm pretty bummed that I'm returning the mouse.* Better, quieter scroll wheel.  They nailed it on this mouse.  Feels amazing, very similar to Microsoft's Surface Precision mouse.Cons:* Ergonomics, specifically:* Narrower, to the point that my ring and pinky fingers drag.  Unlike the 2S which felt great, this mouse is uncomfortably small for my hand.  This is the main reason I'm returning it.* Worse "grip" button.  On the 2S, you could apply pressure on the entire thumb pad.  With the 3, there's a small, somewhat awkwardly-placed divot that forces you to either grip the mouse uncomfortably or press the thumb pad with the side of your knuckle instead of your fingertip.I've ended up ordering a second 2S for work instead.  Bonus that it's cheaper due to being the older version, I guess, but that didn't factor into my decision at all.

I have three computers that I use in my home office, two Apple Macminis and a Dell XPS PC. The three computers utilize just one keyboard (the Logitech MX Keys Keyboard) and one mouse (the MX Master 3) which are located on my desk. I also have one Viewsonic 27" display on the desk. The display is switched between computers using a 3 input HDMI switch. This arrangement makes it very easy to switch between computers while using only one keyboard, one mouse, and one display. It works great!!

Overall am pleased so far in the first month of operation. I haven't tested the feature for using with multiple systems at once.Pros- Asymmetric design is very comfortable to operate- Has a slight texture and is heavy enough to feel precise and secure- Buttons and scroll wheels operate with a nice amount of resistance- Scroll wheel can be toggled for smooth or stepwise feel- Software includes some useful presets for the side wheel and allows lots of customizationCons- Would prefer the forward/back buttons slightly larger- Software wants to run in background and is enabled on startup

I've owned every MX master mouse since version 1. The MX master series are one of the best all-around productivity mice on the market. Ever since I started with version 1, I've been in love with them and keep buying the newest models. The upgrade from version 1 (MX Master) to version 2 (MX Master 2S) was rather minute and arguably not worth it. However this newest version seems to be redesigned with all of the weaknesses and criticism of the previous versions addressed.
The MX Master 2S simply added more (and better) color options to the original. The overall design and shape were practically the same except they removed a dedicated "connect" button on the bottom to a more streamlined and simpler design. Oh yeah, they also changed the logos, big whoop.The new MX Master 3 is a real redesign. The shape is different, the buttons are different, the materials used are different, and the size is overall smaller.The shape and design: The shape is overall wedge design. The look is less angular and more round. I personally had no issues with the previous design but the newest version is supposed to complement the new MX Keyboard, but I don't really see the similarities except for the grey/black color scheme (they're not even the same grey and black). The palm rest area is less wide which I will miss since it was way more comfortable and more natural. They also added these ribs all around the rear which helps with grip but grip was never really an issue. I think it was more of a visual aesthetic. Finally they removed the three LED battery charge indicators with just one solid LED light. This is yet again another simplification of design.The size: The overall size is smaller than the previous versions which isn't a good thing. I understand Logitech wants this to be a more portable mouse which the MX series never was. However I felt this was a mistake as it sacrifices the comfort. I don't have large hands by any measure. However even to me, this mouse seems less comfortable than the previous version. People with larger hands may opt for the 2s.Buttons: The buttons are the first good thing about this mouse. They are redesigned and for the better. The left and right click buttons now extend all the way past the edge which means no chance of hitting the solid (non-button) edge lip. Furthermore, because there is no lip, there's less gunk buildup on the lip edges which is a welcome change. Both scroll wheel ditch the rubber grips for a simple all-metal design. There is less tactile feel but tactile feel for the buttons was never an issue for me. The lack of rubber grip again means less dirt and grime getting stuck in them. They also removed the "click" spin of the wheel which is helpful. I was never a fan of the noisy spin of the wheel. The BIGGEST button change is the side thumb buttons. Logitech FINALLY moved the buttons lower and separated them. The previous two versions were uncomfortably placed next to the scroll wheel and it was near impossible to distinguish them by touch. It never worked for the MX Master, and it was unfathomable why they didn't elect to change it in the MX Master 2s. The buttons are WAY easier to press now and actually usable. The thumb scroll wheel is also larger which is again welcome.The battery is just as excellent as always. It takes weeks of use before I have to charge it and I hope Logitech never changes this!Of course the software and muti-device connections of the MX Master series is still here and still one of the best in the market. I can't stress this enough, I have a Desktop and two laptops. It's super easy to switch between different devices with a single push of the button on the bottom of the mouse. I went from having several mice for several devices to just a single MX Master and you never have to re-pair them once you've done it once. The new MX Keyboard now as this same functionality and it's definitely the best features Logitech devices have.The MX Master 3 is a great upgrade. If you're looking for one of the most versatile mice on the market this should be the top of your list. This is made for professionals - photographers (me), videographers, coders, designers, etc or just a power user with multiple devices that switch often. It really simplifies your life. The only thing it's NOT good for is gaming because the speed and sensitivity just isn't there. The redesign addresses a lot of standing issues with the MX Master series and improves upon them greatly. The only issues I can say is the smaller size and shape have compromised on the comfort of the mouse which was always a longstanding selling-point of the MX Master series. However this is not a deal-breaking change and it can be easily gotten used to.***If this review was useful for you, please give me a like! Thanks!***

It's way too big for smaller hands.  I can barely reach the middle scroll wheel and can't reach the little bonus button on the flat side.  I had wrist pain within 5 minutes.  Come on logitech, I'd like a nice mouse too!  I'm a 5'5 woman by the way.

I picked this up at a Best Buy for the same price as listed here and it's the best productivity mouse I've ever used.

It also comes in a box with no plastic & instructions on how to remove the battery for recycling, which is a nice touch from Logitech.I write a lot of code and do video editing and the scroll wheel on this mouse has been insanely good. The magnetic scrolling on the main wheel feels great and helps me scroll through huge text files with ease. The horizontal scroll wheel is amazing for scrubbing through large timelines easily.I do some casual gaming on the side and the mouse feels great for that. It's probably a little bit heavy for competitive titles but as someone who only plays single player games non-competitively I don't mind. Overall a great mouse for productivity of all sorts and casual gaming!

This mouse is a productivity tool, 100%. If you read long text (or code) files, you need this mouse. The mag wheel is the best around. WOW !! Logitech has done it again. This mouse is superb. The quiet and fluid action and the RESPONSIVE and ACCURATE horizontal scroll wheel - that's just really sweet. I have them all; from the Performance MX, the MX Master, the MX Anywhere 2S, the MX Anywhere 2 and even a few oldies like the M510. With the Performance MX one tilted the scroll wheel to scroll horizontal, basically like the MX Anywhere 2 /2S and even the M510. The MX Master went to a thumb scroll-wheel for horizontal scroll but it sorely lacked fluidity and accuracy. The Forward/Back page 'flippers' were too closely positioned to the thumb scroll to be intuitive. Now, the MX Master 3. Magnetically driven, silent, separation for the Forward/Back buttons from the thumb scroll wheel, accurate scrolling in the horizontal direction. I would always go back to one of my tilt-wheel mice as the tilt-wheel feature was more accurate that the thumb-scroll on the MX Master - but now, I just use the MX Master 3. Finally mastered - Thank you Logitech.

I got this mouse together with the MX Keys keyboard recently. The shape of the mouse is very personal, and I'm not sure if it will fit my hand in the long run. I've never had any carpal tunnel or RSI problems so I think I should be good. What I Love about this mouse is that it is a bit on the heavy side, so it feels very stable to me. The scroll wheel has this awesome capability where if you give it a good spin it almost feels like it disengages from the ratcheting and it scrolls like crazy. Then all you have to do is put your finger on it and it stops immediately. There is this side scroll button that is great for a variety of programmable things. For instance in Excel you can use it to scroll the sheet sideways, or writing a long line of code you can just pull the code editor page to the left.The USB-C charging cable plugs in where traditionally the mouse wire used to go, and you can charge it while using it and it feels natural. I just keep the charging cable plugged in on my desk and pull it out when the battery runs low.One of my pet peeves in Windows mouse is that you have to hack into the registry to change the scroll direction. Ever since I've used a MacBook for a few years, I've gotten to get used to and love the scrolling direction that is reverse from the standard Windows direction. The first thing that I do when I get a new mouse, is change the FlipFlopWheel attribute in the registry. When I did that for this mouse, it did not have an effect, which I did not like at all, until I found that the Logitech Options software actually has a setting for it!!! Amazing how such a little thing can make me THAT happy, but it does :)It's certainly an expensive mouse, but so far I'm happy that I spent the money. Hopefully it'll keep working well for a long time to come.
I use this mouse for work; I mainly use a web-based platform and plenty of excel, and this has improved my workflow with its customizable functions and scrolling wheel.

better than expected to say the lease.

This review is comparing the Master 3 to the Master 2. I used the latter for the better part of a year and loved that mouse, but it was starting to get beat up and decided to ask for the 3 as a Christmas present. I haven't had a chance to put this mouse through its paces, but here are my initial impressions:- Connectivity is as easy as it was with the 2, and I have no issues with intermittent disconnection on Bluetooth. Logi Options makes setup a breeze, walks you through the functions of the mouse if you haven't used one before, and is actually a useful piece of software. The Master 3 functions essentially as a wired mouse, and I doubt anyone but the most intense gamers playing twitch shooters would notice any meaningful delays in movement.- Ergonomically, again nearly identical to the 2. For those that haven't used a MX Master mouse, it's extremely comfortable to use though does take a bit to get used to as it's a big "bulkier" than most mice. The feel is similar to holding a small, somewhat flattened baseball. I have no problem using this mouse for hours a day as a lot of my work is on the computer. There's no meaningful difference between the 2 and the 3, with the 3 just as comfortable as the 2. The 3 does seem to have a more rubberized texture on the body, which I personally like, but I anticipate that that will start to wear to some degree with heavy use.- I LOVE the gesture button, and that's what made me interested in the Master series to begin with. I use a Mac, so the gesture button allows me to replicate the important functions of the trackpad - e.g., quickly switching between desktops, bringing up Expose and Mission Control, etc. - on the mouse. The 3 is no different than the 2 in this regard. The gesture button does feel a little "firmer," but that may be due to the fact that there's no wear on it at this point. If you're a Mac user and you're looking for something with a little more functionality than the Magic Mouse, this is the mouse for you.- I haven't had a chance to test connectivity on multiple devices yet. Assuming this is the same as the 2, this is a very nice feature that generally worked well, though I had occasional issues with my 2 on macOS seemingly not recognizing the device when switching between devices. This was fixable by simply forgetting the mouse and reconnecting it, which really wasn't that inconvenient since Logi Options remembered my settings.- The big difference between the 3 and the 2 is the mechanics of the scroll wheels. The scroll wheels on the 3 are MUCH superior, with a much quieter and smoother mechanism. This is a welcome change and is the primary difference that I've noticed between the two models thus far. The scroll wheel on the 2 would make a clearly audible clicking sound when used in "ratchet" mode, particularly when scrolled quickly, which doesn't happen with the 3.- Another difference is that, on the 3, the forward and back buttons on the side of the mouse, just below the horizontal scroll wheel, are laid out in a way that actually makes sense. These buttons were far too close together on the 2 - literally on top of each other - making it difficult to discriminate between them. On the 3, there's a very small amount of space which makes it easier to figure out which button you're pushing, and they're oriented front/back rather than right on top of each other.. This is another welcome change. See the attached image to see the difference (the Master 3 is on the left, the Master 2 on the right).If you currently have a perfectly functional Master 2, it probably isn't worth the cost to upgrade to 3 as the scroll wheel upgrade and changes layout of the forward/back buttons aren't, in my opinion, worth the $100 cost. However, if your old Master mouse is starting to kick the bucket or you just want to try the latest and greatest, the Master 3 is a very nice continuation of this great series of mice. Especially for Mac users, this is an excellent mouse as you can retain nearly all of the critical functionality of the trackpad with the generally easier use of a full mouse. Highly recommend!

I had tried the original MX Master when it came out and didn't really care for it. The improvements since then make this my favorite mouse ever now. Works out of the box with Linux (even the thumb button is easy to map, registers as a keyboard button). Feels very sturdy and is comfortable. Great battery life and charges with USB-C.

I don’t know why it’s so hard to find a good mouse. I do a lot of programming at work so I am a heavy user and have, in the past, only had luck with a wired gaming mouse (e.g. Corsair). Many of the wireless mouses I’ve used, including Logitech, have been subpar, unreliable, and/or end up breaking with normal use. Knock on wood, this guy seems to be different. In fact it’s really nice. It fits beautifully in my hand, tracks well, and the scroll wheel... well I don’t know if I could ever go back to a plastic mechanically ratcheting scroll wheel again.I hesitated deciding to write this review because it is still unknown as to whether the thing holds up over time. To me, that is maybe the most important facet of a mouse at this price point. The mouse feels solid though and I’ll try and edit this review if it breaks under normal use.

I like this mouse but the software is so buggy.After customizing the buttons, sometimes something happens with the Logitech Options software running in the background that nothing works the way it was configured.  All the Logitech processes have to be killed and restarted for it to work again.  It's the worst.Sometimes the buttons do double clicks or have delayed clicks after they're pressed.  In a browser, click the back button is like hitting the back button in the browser twice.  I set the thumb button to be the Enter key, yet sometimes when I click it, it opens up the virtual desktops in Windows.  Not even remotely close to the behavior of hitting the Enter key.  After double checking to see if the button configuration was reset, it still shows as configured for the Enter key behavior.When it works, it's great.  Just wish there wasn't a need for the Logitech Options software to be running in order for customized buttons to function the way they're configured.

This is another Logitech design win. Sure it's a premium price, but if you're going to use something 9 hours a day, it might be worth investing a few bucks Into it.The weighting is nice, the accuracy spot on, and the thumb scroll is a life saver for navigating massive spreadsheets. The  thumb buttons have a little better placement over the original MX, and hopefully, the updated gesture button will hold up longer as that's what finally gave out on my original MX Master after years of daily use.

I’ve used a lot of mouses (or mice as they call them). This has to be one of the better ones though I’m not surprised because Logitech has been a producer of good input devices for a long time. All the buttons and controls work as you would like, it’s very comfortable in the hand, easily programmable buttons. Just a good mouse overall, highly recommended. Oh and it doesn’t take up a lot of USB slots because I can share the transmitter between a Logitech keyboard and this mouse. The Logitech keyboard, the master MX is also awesome! Disclaimer: I’m a graphic designer not a gamer.

I purchased this mouse for a number of reasons.... but the deciding factor was the horizontal scroll wheel on the thumb.  Unfortunately this intermittently works 50% of the time.  Opening the logitech app will often get it working again but it's extremely frustrating and makes this mouse a nuisance more than a productivity enhancer.
Worked well got a month then went slowly downhill till it died

I had 3 generations of MX Logitech mice and it's time for me to try something else.The good: nice looking, ergonomic shape, charged by USB C so future proof from this point of view, no need to keep buying batteries as it has internal battery, better placed and more rewarding buttons that the previous model (MX 2S)The bad: USB Dongle is not USB C (so if you have a new Laptop or will buy one in the future, you can only use Bluetooth.) Really great rubber feeling in the hand.Feels the entire palm. I like the fact that it kinda go to sleep when you don't use it for a few moment.This mouse is gold. But it would have been diamond to me if the clicks were quiet.But overall I love it.Can't wait to buy its keyboard.

I was so excited to find the newest version of my beloved Performance MX mouse.  Unfortunately, this one did not function correctly.  It rarely accepted clicks (mainly for selection but also would not highlight selected areas) and it moved all over my screen when I tried to select an item/icon.  Horrid! Don't waste your money on this one!
I love the scroll wheel. But me and another friend who bought it both feel like it's too long.

I never knew what I was missing. I've never had an expensive mouse before. This one was easily twice what I've ever paid in the past. Worth every penny. Comfortable to use. Very responsive and accurate. I use it mostly for browsing, but also for several hours of work on Fusion 360 where it really shines. I'm not a gamer so can't speak to that.  Last game I played was pong and that was when it connected to a television--no home computers existed.
Was a gift to son.... he likes it very much

***Update***It's been a few months now and I've taken my MX Master 3 back out of the drawer.I've been using it exclusively now, and don't remember the last time I wanted to switch back to the Performance MX.In short, it's grown on me. Here's why:• Very lightweight• I'm now apparently hooked on having a horizontal scroll wheel• OUTSTANDING battery life. I've only charged this because I get nervous about how eerily long it's been since the previous charge. I've easily gone over two months of daily usage without any charging.• Bluetooth connectivity. That basically upgrades my laptop by one USB port. That's huge.• I have a dual boot OS. This makes the device-pairing button very handy.***Update End; Original review follows***This is objectively a very good mouse.However I am honestly disappointed with my MX Master 3.The problem is that I owned a Logitech MX Revolution & currently own multiple Performance MX mice.I absolutely love them, but they're are getting old and worn. So I decided to see what Logitech had to offer in their new models.I tried to like it, but after a week of exclusive use, I put it in a drawer and have gone back to my Performance MX.Pros:-Bluetooth connection capability is great. Freeing up a USB port by not requiring a receiver is a big plus.  Both the wireless receiver & bluetooth connectivity has been responsive and solid in my experience.-The MX Master 3 is lighter than the Performance MX.-The ridged texture on the thumb rest/button is an improvement. You feel like you have more control with this enhancement.Cons:-The MX Master 3 is shorter lengthwise compared to the Performance MX. The shorter length doesn't support the bottom of my palm very well, causing my wrist to droop. This is also made worse by the taller height of the MX Master 3.-I had issues with the behavior of the scroll wheel on webpages. The free-spin worked fine, but the incremental setting seems coarse and abrupt compared to the Performance MX. The moment that I stopped using my MX Master 3 was when I got frustrated with the scrolling action while browsing the web.I had to keep switching to free-spin to get back to parts of the webpage that the incremental scroll wouldn't stop on.*****(This turned out to be a software issue, not the mouse. See update at bottom for)Overall, it really is a nice mouse, but apparently I've been spoiled.Maybe Logitech should consider creating a model that uses the superior form of the Performane MX and add some of more beneficial modern tech (e.g. Bluetooth, lighter & longer-lasting battery)Until then, I will stick with the Performance MX as long as I can.

First off, this mouse is amazing.  Having a side-scrolling wheel is great for large excel documents, or for a programmer, when that code starts drifting off the page a bit.Additionally, I didn't realize this mouse had a ratchet AND free-spinning scroll wheel for the main up/down scroller.  This is honestly the most amazing feature ever, the mouse scrolls with a detente just like any regular mouse, but if you have a large document you can flick it with some force and it will just spin for 10-15 seconds, and the spin is amazing.  Nice and silent.  The wheel has some weight to it which gives it some inertia.  I had fun spinning the wheel, then clicking into a window and automatically seeing the document start shooting down.  So fun!Now to the BAD!!!1) There is no slot for the RF dongle.  I use Bluetooth on my main computer, but I could still want to connect to a foreign computer when I'm in the field, and if there's no holder for that on the mouse itself, there's no way I can figure out some way to always have it on me.2) The side-scroll is a LITTLE forward for my hand, I would have liked if it was a little farther back.  I find myself having to re-position my hand and reach for it when I need to use it.3) My third finger (ring finger?) rests just to the right of the right clicker... and although the placement feels perfect and I can get "underneath" the mouse for easy re-positioning, I find that my finger lands on a sharp edge which makes my finger sore.4) The main scroller just broke an hour ago, I've been hoping that it will re-fix itself, but currently it will only free-spin and not ratchet.  That means that I'm constantly bumping it and making my window jump.****EDIT****My last point (reason #4) for giving this a 4-star review was because I thought my ratchet-scroll had broken and got jammed into freespin-only.  Turns out that the button on the mouse next to the scroll-wheel (which is usually used to change DPI) is actually an ON/OFF enable for the rachet/freespin mode.  I don't know why you would want to turn off such a nice feature ever... and really I think it's silly to have a button which toggles OFF such a great instrument, but for whatever reason, I missed the instructions which detailed this functionality and I must have hit the button by accident without realizing it.  Review changed back to 5-star but again, this mouses still isn't perfect (9 out of 10, or 4.5 star).For ERGONOMICS it gets a 3/5 because of the sharp "edge" that your third finger rests on.  Two weeks later, it is still making my ring finger sore where my finger meets the edge.  That is poor design if you ask me, all it takes is one day of testing to discover that it's uncomfortable.  Fix this and it's a 5/5.
A little different than previous model but after getting used to its great.

I am a first time adopter. I haven't owned the previous versions of this mouse so these are my initial thoughts.Pros: The scrolling is very satisfying. The ergonomics is also great. I come from "designer" mouses such as the Surface Arc and also the Apple Magic Mouse 2. These mouses began to give me wrist problems and it also tired out my fingers a lot. This mouse fits very well in my hands and I don't feel that it will give me any problems.There are reviewers who have said that there is jitter. I am running macOS Catalina 10.51.1 and have zero jitter. Also, there are reviewers who are concerned about input monitoring "from your keyboard"; I'm fairly certain that macOS Catalina's improved security mechanisms are at play here. I believe that this needs to be enabled in the security settings because of the extra mouse buttons which can be registered as key strokes (such as the gesture button and wheel mode shift which can be modified). Some apps from Apple themselves warn with certain permissions as well.Cons: Like others, it's a bummer that the receiver is still not USB-C. It is especially inconvenient with modern MacBooks that need dongles to use USB 2 or 3. This led me to use bluetooth so at least it won't be that inconvenient.Another thing I noticed is that it is hard to rest my finger on the scrolling wheel; web pages move very subtly so I assume it is very sensitive, even in ratchet mode. Maybe my device is defective, so I'll exchange it to see if that's the issue.The other issue I have is that the only way to view the battery status is to use their application.

Crisp action in your palm.  The feel of quality materials and construction. Convenient USB recharging.  Upgraded software compared to my last model (Download it from Logitech.)  Long-lasting power, especially if the mouse is powered off when not in use.  Can be cable connected (supplied) to a USB port and charged while in use.I AM NOT A POWER USER anymore, so I fumbled a bit with the realization that my Logitech WAVE keyboard was not compatible with this mouse.  I purchased an MX Keyboard from Amazon and was back in business.  CONS:  Few of us really need a $100. mouse.  Few of us really need a $100. keyboard.  My idea of gaming online is Microsoft Solitaire Premium...so go figure.  My son has the memory and the dexterity to use multi-key commands in gaming.  I would need a dedicated game controller.

 BT and Logitech USB dongle, it would of been nice for a new mouse like this to use USB C but I guess they figure there are two customers. Customers using the latest hardware will just connect via BT and those connecting to older type hardware would use the older USB A connection.This mouse is larger than the previous MX version. This mouse is more of a palm mouse rather than one you maneuver with your fingers. It does fit snug within your palm with easy reach to all shortcut buttons and scroll wheels. Mouse is very quiet and precision is spot on for a company that U would expect such quality.Matte grippy rubberized coating.Software is complete with allowing for customization of buttons and shortcuts.Convenient that it charges via USB C, wish it had a dock to charge rather than having to plug in a cable each time to charge.Super useful that with this day in age everyone has multiple devices and this can be paired with up to three devices with an easy button press underneath.If you like palm mouses with extreme customization, smooth functionality and reliability then Logitech has brought it to the table.

I really like this mouse. Before the MX Master 3 I was using the Logitech G305 which is also an amazing mouse.However, the comfort and ability to switch to different computers is absolutely worth every penny to me.Very pleased with this purchase.

I lost my MX Master 2, so I gave version 3 a try. It keeps all of the good features while improving some annoyances!- Having a separate row for the fwd/back keys is nice. (I configure one of them to act as middle-click.)- The scrolling is even smoother.- USB-C 😍- Given that I have big hands, I was concerned about the shape change. I got used to it very quickly.

generally the mouse works, but it's special buttons do not (thumb scroll, back/forward, wheel button). I am on OSX 10.15 .1 and have installed and uninstalled their sw several times and can't get it to work. I do not recommend buying this for a Mac.

It works as good or even better than the original MX mouse. My biggest complaint about the Original MX mouse was the short battery life since there was only one AA rechargeable battery in it. (They could have put at least 2 in their)Their lower end mice have 2 batteries and last for a long time) This mouse has lasted over 2 weeks so far..and we will see how much longer it will keep going.  Yet it is missing one side button from the original MX mouse which I used all the time and miss.  OTHERWISE I LOVE THIS MOUSE AND RECOMMEND IT TO OTHERS. AND I DON'T GAME.

While there have been some negative feedback on this product, I offered some of that negative feedback, I have since worked a bit with this product (it really didn't require all that much) and have found it to be a very good device after all.  Very often, some products take, for whatever reason, a bit of settling in time.  And sometimes the product isn't the problem, it is the user.  That was the problem in my case.  Any way, the mouse is fairly much a plug and play item.  So far will will give it a five star rating and an apology.

REALLY THIS IS SO BAD MY OLDER Logitech MX Master BATTERY LASTED LIKE 4 OR 5 MONTHSALSO i CANT GET USED TO THE BACK AND FORWARD BUTTONSLIKED MY OLD MX BETTER AND WAS WAY CHEAPERI GOT TO PLUG THIS ONE UP TO CHARGE NOW
Its the best for editing photos or videos and professional use

Out of the box, this was clearly the nicest mouse I have used. Great feel in the hand and wonderful functionality. Once I had it set up I discovered all sorts of features I hadn't known of, such as Flow (that lets me use it on two adjacent laptops, just passing from screen to screen).If it holds up, I would happily recommend or buy another when I wear this out.

You can only use this mouse if you "Allow Logitech to monitor all input from your keyboard, even while using other applications".  Even Apple on their MacOS user guide red flags this concern.  DO NOT purchase this mouse.  It also feels cheap in the hand as a mouse.
Dead on arrival, replacement unit great, exactly what you can expect from a MX mouse

Once you get used to it, and to using all the wheels and geastures, it just disappears in your hand, and get you to be far more productive. One of the best mouses I ever used in my 25+ years of using computers.

I have been using this mouse for two months now. I have been using different low to mid tier mouses in the past. I finally jumped on this MX train and it has been a good decision.Pros-Let's talk about the scroll wheel first. The "infinity" magspeed scroll on this mouse is AMAZING. I could scroll through pages of code smoothly in any code editor. However, there was a bit of a lag when browsing through web pages. I believe this might be because of my i5 processor as other applications handled it well.-The ergonomics on this mouse are just brilliant. The thumb buttons are exactly where they need to be and are fully customizable.Cons-The only one I can think of is build quality. I have paid a premium for this product. I wish Logitech would come up with better quality construction materials.

Feels slightly lighter. Spins faster and smoother. The back and forward buttons are in more logical positions. I had to get this due to a few improvements, but also for the usb-c charging connector. I purchased the new MX Master Keyboard with usb-c a couple weeks ago. The MX keyboard has an advertised battery recharge cycle of 10 days. I have always kept my MX Master mouse plugged in all the time, so now, with both devices having usb-c charge receptacles, it's natural for me to put the charging cable back into the keyboard after topping of the mouse now and then. Great ergo, Logi.
Set up was straightforward using with laptop and desktop, would highly recommended to anyone that spends a great amount of time using a computer. Switching between devices is flawless
I like it a lot and with Amazon taking care of my Prime Shipping It's a no brainer.

I had an MX Master 2S and based on reviewed debated whether the upgrade to 3 was worth it. It totally is. Not only is it slightly more responsive, the back/forward buttons are in a much better place, and side scroll wheel is much better (larger and smoother), and the main scroll wheel is awesome now. Also the software for the 3 is much more advanced and customizable.
scroll wheel stopped working properly after two days. for 100 bucks it is such a bummer.

Since its predecessor (the Performance MX) was first introduced in 2010, the MX Master is the only mouse I buy. I use a mouse intensively for 8-10 hours a day at work and at least 2-3 hours a day at home almost daily, and I've bought over a dozen of these for my own use over the past decade. The mouse is well made, precise, and the free-spinning wheel is invaluable for some applications (the reason I bought it originally). The battery lasts me about a week of heavy use between charges, and it recharges fully from empty in a couple of hours. Downsides for some might be size (if you have small hands), weight (it's medium, not light), free-spinning scroll takes a little getting used to (but you don't have to use the feature), price (if you are budget conscious). Otherwise I would highly recommend the mouse to anyone who depends on a mouse to get their work done.
Its nice fit for me

At my home-office I've been using a trackball for a decade. It just feels better to me to have an immobile device to control the pointer on my computer. However, they're getting harder to find, and, frankly, not much new technology is being introduced through them. So, time to explore mouse options.Honestly, first one I tried and I'm absolutely in love. The MX Master is an excellent mouse. The ergonomic feel is very nice, especially the thumb rest and split between the "grip" area at your palm & thumb, and the clicking surfaces under your fingers. It just feels nice. Yeah, I'm having to get used to moving my hand around again, but the responsiveness of this mouse is excellent. I suspect it'll make getting good screen captures easier (moving a pixel at a time required a very clean trackball).The button distribution and behavior is excellent. I like have a wheel, but I want it to be of the click variety, not that free movement. This one does both. Better still, it automatically switches depending on how fast you spin it, which is excellent. You can control this manually as well. The wheel also clicks, which is great for web browsing where I've long been used to opening new tabs using it. The introduction of a side-scroller is taking me some getting used to, but I'm digging it. I also like the context & gesture button. I'm not sure I like the defaults of the gestures, all controllable and customizable. The other two buttons, also customizable add more functionality.Overall, this does way more than my trackball did (hence my interest in changing). I like the feel and the behavior of the buttons. The clicks are solid and satisfying, not squishy like some mice I've tried. I would say that this is a very good mouse and once I'm used to it, I'm going to be extremely happy with it. I'm already in love with the depth of functionality.

I got this mouse as a gift. I am a happy user of the first generation of the MX Master (almost 3 years) and very briefly used the second generation.The Mx Master 3 is a step back in ergonomics for me because the top of the mouse is not as "flat" on the previous models and that "spike" that is roughly between the thumb and the index finger is poking into the hand, making it uncomfortable.The button under the thumb is impossible to press, since it so much smaller. The original mouse has the button set such, that one can press it with the side of the thumb (the button as raised above the surrounding surface). The new model has the button surrounded by rigid edges under the soft cover, so that the button does not protrude (the button is recessed - that's fine for a button on a wall, but absolutely not for a button that is supposed to be pressed by the side of a thumb). My thumb essentially rests on the two edges of the button and I cannot just roll it and press it like I can on the MX Master 1. (See photo).Generally, the mouse is not as comfortable. The thumb wheel is not close to the thumb, so the thumb needs to move up about 1 cm to even touch the side scroll.The "freespin" does not spin as long as it does on the first generation. It is noticeably slower, therefore it stops earlier. It does not feel even a little bit more precise or faster as advertised.While it is quieter, the scroll is mushy, does not react to fast movements.If anyone is looking into getting a mouse from the Master series, you'd be better off buying the previous models, especially since they are much cheaper now that the third model is out.

I have been using logitech since mx darkfield. Although the general outline was kept the design get improved greatly. Compared to previous versions, MX Master 3 fits in my hand very well and I can use it quite a long time. Personally, I loved the side buttons and scroll. So far this design is superior among the other Logitech MX series.I feel the clicker sound is a little softer and it doesn't make too much noise like the previous ones. I mainly used this at work, especially for 3D modeling. I also used it a couple of times at home for gaming. It is compatible with many games including FPS games like counterstrike or games like Witcher.Since I only have a windows system, I do not know how it would work on a mac. I recommend this mouse.
The device is great and smoth, It's ability to connect to 3 devices in the same time is a plus, my only con about it that it is clicking sound is loud and I don't like to have this clicky sound.
Long battery life fits well in the hand
The mouse did not work/turn on. I called Customer Service and they said it was defected.  Will update my review when I get a replacement.

It turns out that the wheel locks when the mouse is powered off and will spin freely once it's turned on. So keep that in mind. This mouse is awesome though - ergonomic and sturdy. Lots of customization options and great for productivity. Highly recommend.

I'm a fanatic for control by mouse. I've used Logitech mice with this kind of scroll wheel for years. This mouse ups the game with better ergonomics (still could be better - as could most mice). Many configuration options. I use the side scroll wheel (default is horizontal scroll) as zoom in and out, press the scroll wheel to minimize the current window, buttons for back and for closing current tab or window. And four gesture commands available (I have refresh, scroll to top,,,). The wheel action is the best yet. I have app specific commands for outlook, firefox, etc.
Still positive is that I move a laptop between home and office and have one of these mice at each location and each with it's own usb receiver in a docking station. I can move between seamlessly. The old logitech system one had to run logitech connect whenever the location was switched.I also have an MX Anywhere 2S for travel that is included in the LogiOptions configuration software.The only negative is that LogiOptions sometimes has to be run on startup to get custom configuration loaded. Tried to have LogiOptions run on startup, but it won't for some reason. So, I have a hotkey to run it when needed. Minor inconvenience.Overall, highly recommended.
Great mouse

I did not like this mouse at all and it was returned the day I got it. The thumb section feels horrible as the two cheap mushy buttons jam into your thumb in standard holding position. This alone made it absolutely useless to me. I cannot believe (according to other reviews) that other users can actually tolerate this incredibly annoying shortcoming.

this mouse is 100% sick , everything is the best cept for 2 minor downs:the 4th and 5th buttons could be better , yet still pretty goodand the software for linux flow...if anyone knows of the flow software for linux plzzzzz lmk necromancer011@yahoo.comvery very good mouse
Scrolling wheel is laging

Using on a Windows 10 Lenovo desktop.  I'm not a gamer, just email, surfing, Office stuff, etc.  Love this mouse.  Easy to install, feels solid and responsive.  Happy with Logitech products, a bit more expensive, but reliable, well-thought out and worth the extra cost.

The latest of many Logitech mice I've used over the years, and my favorite to date.  I particularly like: the center scroll wheel options, the thumb wheel (although I don't need to use it all that often) and its application by application programmability.  It's also got a nice smooth glide, no doubt benefiting from how light it is.  I've had it for many weeks now, and only needed to plug it in for recharging once.  Having said that, I do make a point of turning it off when I'm not using it.

After using the MX Master for a long time then upgrading to the MX Master 2, I was hoping the 3 would go back to the focus on ergonomics of the palm grip... so glad it's back! The curve to the thumb is much more aligned to how I hold the mouse, the scroll wheel is surprisingly better than the amazing MX 2, and it feels much lighter in weight yet is heavy enough to move accurately and not feel cheap. The higher pitched clicking noise is different, but it gets tuned out very quickly. Solid mouse in the line and highly recommended!

Note: This review compares the Logitech Performance MX to the MX Master 3 (I have not used the models in-between).  I purchased the mouse from an online Amazon competitor and will be returning it (apparently at my expense -I should have purchased it from Amazon)I really wanted to like this mouse, but three things made it a non-starter for me.1. I don't use and don't like the scroll wheel on the thumb-side of the mouse.  It is placed where the forward and back buttons used to be (Those have been moved lower and are now awkward to push with my thumb).2. The pad placement at the bottom of the mouse (with a longer one located beneath the thumb), creates a weird sideways drag as I move the mouse.  As I move it around my desk, I feel like I'm fighting with the mouse to keep it straight.3. The laser doesn't track as well as the Logitech Performance MX mouse does on my glass desk, causing it to skip fairly frequently.  I've never had that happen with the standard MX mouse.
Changed my mouse life. Forever.
Fast Shipping ! And good item
Amazing for editing and also gets all the normal jobs done as well

So far I've used this mouse for a month and have had no issues with it at all. It seamlessly moves from my PC to my Macbook without any issues. Battery life is great so far and the overall feel of the mouse is just right for my hands. Great overall.
this is my first time buying mx master series mouse. like other people, my mouse scroll wheel has delay/no response issue. i am very disappointed of it

This mouse was advertised as perfect for architects and engineers, neither of which I am. Setup was easy; just plug in the USB receiver, switch the mouse on, and go.
My current wired mouse has left- and right-click buttons and an up-down scroll wheel. This mouse has a few more buttons that will take some practice using. There's the left-right scroll wheel. Underneath this wheel are two page navigation buttons: the front one is for going forward one page, the back one is for going back one page. There are a couple of other buttons that I don't think I'll ever use.This mouse is taller than I'm used to, so it's awkward for me to hold. The buttons aren't so easy to reach. Several reviewers mentioned that this mouse isn't for people with small hands, but I have large hands for a woman. Maybe it will get easier to use with time.

I've been using a performance MX mouse at work and home for 5-6 years now.I recently upgraded to this mouse...Cons: The clicks on this mouse are louder than I expected. The scroll wheel will auto "infinity scroll" if you scroll too quickly. The power button (on the bottom) is no longer located in a position that allows for one hand support.Pros:It's super light! Love the usbc. Gray looks better than black. The additional scroll wheel on the thumb is appreciated, way better than a left right rocker on the MMB. The improved multitask thumbbutton is also appreciated, looks less flimsy.Unsure:The forward & back buttons may be a bit too small, but I'm at only 15 hours of use on the mouse.Overall great mouse, complaints are tiny and overshadowed by the rest of my experience with the mouse
Very ergonomic, love all of the features. Very pleased to learn that both the scroll wheels functioned as expected on android

I must tell ya'll... I am loving this mouse! I spend a lot of time on the computer. Between being a full-time data analyst and then graduate school... I literally use the computer everyday. I have gone through numerous mice and because I have a laptop I will just stop using them because I find that many are not comfortable to use for long periods of time.This one deserves a gold crown. First - it fits my hand perfectly. I do have pretty small hands so I can't speak for everybody.The response time is crazy fast. The scroll wheel is super sharp. It looks good and it feels good. I also am shook that you can pair it to multiple devices at the same time. This is perfect for me since my computer for school is a PC but my work computer is a MacBook.

I was using the Microsoft Sculpt ergonomic keyboard and mouse for my office setup for the laptop. I had used earlier versions of Microsoft ergonomic keyboard for years and was happy. But this time, with the sculpt, I started getting issues within a year - keyboard missing characters and mouse being slow and erratic (even after replacing batteries). I got this mouse for review more than a month ago.All I can say is Wow. Excellent response for mouse movements. The middle button works well for me for Linux cut and paste operations as well. So easy to hold with your hand but this is for right handed use and might be a challenge/adjustment for left hand use.Battery life - don't know and have to wait for few more months, so far so good.Plug and play install and didn't need to do anything other than installing battery and plugging in the USB dongle on Windows 10 Professional laptop.Highly recommended for serious computer users - for both coding soldiers and powerpoint warriors..
