 Didn't buy on Amazon, but figured this info is most appropriate here. The scroll wheel jiggles back and forth on its own slightly after scrolling in ratchet mode almost every time if you gently flick it enough to get some momentum, but not enough to engage smooth scrolling..or if you simply power the mouse down in ratchet mode and scroll with any force at all. It doesn't move enough to register a scroll, but enough to provide additional tactile feedback that FEELS like more ratchets of the wheel, so the feedback on-screen is not consistent with the tactile feedback coming from the mouse. I've used previous MX Master mice with the previous gen scroll wheel, and they do not behave similarly at all. If you watch reviews of the V3 with close up shots of the reviewer interacting with the scroll wheel, you can see it in review videos too. It feels like the mouse is still scrolling, but it's really just.....kind of vibrating. Love everything else about the mouse, but this is infuriating, and NOBODY seems to be talking about it. I do not believe it is possible to patch in software, as it is reproducible with the mouse powered down in ratchet mode. It really just makes the mouse seem unpolished like a not quite finished piece of tech, and I would not expect this sort of unfinished/unrefined feel on a $100 mouse.EDIT: Attaching a slow-mo video that shows exactly what I'm talking about

The size of the forward/back buttons by the just below the horizontal scroll button are way to small. They are like slivers so its hard to use your thumb to go forward/backward. The side button could sure be  alot bigger.

Thanks! Finally, you did it right with the usb-c charging port!!! Please, remove the ancient and inconvenient micro-usb port from all of your peripherals. I am waiting for all the gaming mice to go USB-C! I no longer have to carry an extra cable for my mouse!

The only improvement for this mouse compared to MX 2s is the horizontal scroll wheel, which is bigger and positioned better. Everything else is a downgrade from MX 2s. The material is less comfortable. If you use Macbook Pro, the vertical scroll does not behave correctly. This is both hardware and software bugs with the new vertical wheel. Very disappointed. Consider MX 2s or Triathlon instead.

I've had many, many of the high end Logitech mice throughout the years, and I can definitely say this is the nicest one yet. Ergonomically it's fantastic, and although all the other Logitechs I've had were great as far as build quality, but this one feels like a step up. Everything just feels so smooth and precise. Definitely a must have if you're working on a computer 8 hours a day.
LOVE IT!

Amazing. Hands down THE BEST mouse I have EVER used. I am not a gamer so I cannot really speak to that, but the mouse is responsive and a pleasure to use. The gestures are a game changer and the scroll-wheel is addicting (I know that sounds absurd, but you have to just use it to see what I'm on about here).The unit is rechargeable via provided usb cable and even a single minute of charge gives you hours of workability. I got this in combination with the MX keys and could not be happier.

The wheel is fixed.  Last year, when my old Logitech Performance MX mouse gave up the ghost I purchased the Logitech MX Master 2S mouse and found the mouse wheel on it unusable, it would rock back and forth when letting go over it moving the web page or spreadsheet or word doc.. making using the mouse infuriating.  I thought it was defective only to learn (many phone calls, exchanged products) that it was a ‘feature’.  No thanks.When I received the MX Master 3 I was flooded with relief when I started using it and the smooth scrolling wheel (that did not move when let go of) was back.  I love this mouse.Installation.The Logitech Options app had a lot of problems when setting up the MX Master 3 mouse.  The screen would black out and lock up and starting about 10% of the time.  When trying to apply application specific profiles the application locked up.  I finally just got the basics set and left the application alone.Usage.I find the mouse wheel on the MX Master 3 to be one of the most useful and smooth of any mouse I’ve used.  Out of the box the mouse sensitivity was way off and had to muck about with the Logitech Options app to get that set to my satisfaction.The forward and back buttons by the thumb are just not right yet.  They feel too small and in the wrong location, like they should be further forward.  My thumb seems to always rest on the forward and I would prefer it rest on the back or in the middle, but the mouse button layout is not designed out for that to be natural.  I find the thumb wheel to be really useful when I remember it exists.  Like switching tabs with it in a web browser.I have large hands.  The mouse feels different than my old Performance MX mouse (even though they look the same) but still feels comfortable for me.Overall exceedingly pleased with the MX Master 3 mouse.

I heavily use the following software:- Revit- Autocad- Bluebeam- ExcelFunctionality:This mouse is by and large the best mouse I have every owned, there are tons of preset options that you can set for the buttons or scroll wheels and if there is not an option listed that you would like you can enter in a keystroke as the function for one of the buttons or scrollers. The scrollers can do more than just move up dwn lft rght or zoom, they can toggle between bluebeam documents, tabs in the browser, views in revit as well as other functions. The support software for the mouse is EXTREMELY responsible and reliable which I love, as soon as you change a setting it is changed there is no latency at all. The 'hyper scroll' feature can be turned off or toned down to whatever sensitivity that you prefer which is nice.By far the best part about the mouse is that you can set different profiles for any program. All programs default to whatever your global setting is but you can set a local setting for everything from scrolling sensitivity to button functionality depending on what program you are using. They have a few programs listed like excel and photoshop or something listed on the website or description as options for making unique profiles but you can set any program to have its own profile. Sort of weird that they would make it feel somewhat exclusive which made me apprehensive when looking to get this mouse.I did not purchase this mouse off of amazon, my company purchased this mouse for me.(in case it lists me as an unverified purchase that is why)

I've been a proud owner of every MX Master mouse and the 3 just makes everything better. I especially love that it finally charges over USB-C just like everything else on my desk and the new scroll wheel is *really* nice too.

I bought the entire MX setup and the mouse is easily the stand out winner. Best mouse I’ve ever used. Silky smooth action with gestures. Perfectly tactile buttons that have a satisfying click. Smooth, accurate scrolling at all speeds. Easy to use secondary buttons. Most importantly, the ergonomics makes clicking all day a breeze. I deal with wrist pain from years of using awful input devices. After using this device I can honestly say it’s taken away my wrist shoulder and neck pain. I also do not get a twinge of pain with every click and scroll like I do with lesser mice.

Logitech decided to make this mouse narrower and taller than the Mx Master 2S. The result for medium to large hands is the pinky and ring finger do not have an adequate place to rest or grip - which the 2S possessed. To me, Logitech values aesthetics over ergonomics. It's all in the marketing.

Smooth and precise, but this mouse is just too small. I haven't had a decent size mouse since my Logitech MX Laser. Could also be tilted forward and to the right a little more for better large-hand ergonomics. None of this is an issue for most people, but I needed a mouse I could use extensively for 8-12 hrs per day. My wrist hurts now.
it is a mx master, and now with usb-c, worth upgrading from my OG mx master

I'm not a gamer, but I spend a great deal of time working on my laptops. Since I have several, I love the fact that the mouse can easily connect via bluetooth to each of them without having to reconfigure anything. I also love the ergonomics, and the solid feel the mouse gives you when you operate it. Speaking of it, the mouse works great and it's extremely smooth on every surface. One more thing: I have big hands, and the mouse size is perfect for me. I say that because someone with small hands might find the mouse a little big. Try it before committing to it.All in all, a great product worth the cost.
One more excellent revision of the MX Master series.

Very comfy.  I love the scroll wheels.  However, the left thumb button where you are supposed to be able to push 4 ways for 4 different commands doesn't work right.  It's fairly useless.Great tracking.  Again, another but.  BUT THERE IS NO WAY TO SWITCH DPI on this thing with its 14+ buttons.  Why?The Logitech software is meh.  And to be honest I hate proprietary software as it usually just usually memory for no reason and crashes a lot.

I've always loved the MX series. The aesthetic and ergonomic design is top notch. The software works as intended. The best part is the scroll wheel... Unfortunately, it's wireless capabilities suck. The Bluetooth and RF USB adapter both have an incredibly short range. Anything solid in the way like a desk, your laptop's frame, a stone coaster or glass... they all interfere with the connection even when the receiver is less than a meter away. furthermore there is noticeable lag and jitter when playing video games. To be honest, a designer in Photoshop would notice it too. It's tracking accuracy is sporadic to say the least a downright disappointing overall. Mice like the Razer Mamba or Corsair Dark Core, while marketed for "gaming," have superior wireless technology inside them. It's a real shame that Logitech puts ten year old wireless technology inside their top of the line mouse. It makes no sense.On top of all that, there's no dock or Qi charging. I have to keep a dedicated cable at my desk for this mouse to charge. Not a big deal on it's own, but even when plugged in it still relies on wireless for it's connection to the computer.Overall, Logitech made a good looking and feeling mouse, but put bad tech inside of it for the part that matters most. I would not recommend this mouse unless all you plan to do with it is brows the web. even then you'll notice the poor connection.

This mouse is pretty nice. One thing I like about it is that it give you the option of having both a USB plug as well as Bluetooth connectivity. There is no slot on the mouse to hold the USB plug unfortunately. This mouse is a big upgrade from past Logitech mouses as it use a type c plug to charge. The type c cable is not extremely long as it feels meant for being charged with a laptop. This usual makes for faster charging as there is a built in battery inside the mouse.  The mouse battery can last several weeks before needing to be recharged and will auto sleep if it is not active or not connected. The mouse does have a pretty good feel. It does not hurt my wrist or anything while I am using it. The mouse scrolling wheel is pretty nice and accurate. You can scroll down at fast speeds or you can get precision scrolling. The material of the mouse is smooth but provides grip so you do not slide off the mouse. It is a fairly big mouse but you can take it on the go if needed. The USB dongle is pretty small so you can take it on the go but be careful not to lose it. If you want to not have to worry about the dongle you have the option of Bluetooth which in my opinion is a lot better in terms of connectivity. You get more range with this mouse on Bluetooth then you do with dongle. It is a pretty easy setup and with all the new laptops having standard Bluetooth, this mouse works perfectly. You can get about fifteen feet away from the computer/laptop before you start noticing any lag. The response time on the mouse is accurate. You do not have any lag time with this mouse on USB or Bluetooth. The mouse has a pretty sensitive DPI making it decent for gaming as well if need be. I would not say it is the best for gaming as I am not a fan for wireless mouses being used for gaming. You can adjust the DPI on the mouse. Overall I think this mouse is a good investment if you are looking for a decent gaming mouse while also having a good mouse for working on things like financing and powerpoints.

The Logitech MX Master 3 Advanced Wireless Mouse - Graphite is a well constructed mouse, but the most important feature of the Options Software is not present (there is no pointer acceleration setting).  The only way to get accurate pointer motion is to lower the pointer speed, but this will result in having to move the mouse 6 inches left or right for a dual monitor setup.  Also the Options Software disables SetPoint which has an acceleration setting.

Logitech’s MX Master line of mice has become a gold standard for office mice. This year’s edition of the series brings improvements, albeit iterative, over the previous generation. The MX Master 3 is responsive and precise enough to negotiate sophisticated business and creative tasks even when placed on glass desktops. Unfortunately, gamers that are into high FPS shooter genres still may not get the responsiveness they desire from the MX Master 3.There’s a ton to like about this mouse starting with the ergonomics. If you’re right-handed (sorry fellow lefties) this mouse was designed to provide a rich feature-set at your fingertips. The revamped electromagnetic scroll wheel might be the most lauded feature due to the stunning silence with which it operates. There are also gesture controls, a second scroll wheel and and dedicated forward and back buttons nestled within thumb’s reach.Connectivity and battery life are amazing on the MX Master 3. The MX Master 3 can be used on Windows, Mac and Linux. There are even edge controls where dragging and dropping files from on synced, open systems is as simple as dragging the mouse to the corner of the screen. Then there’s the issue of battery life. I charged this mouse once (and gladly did so via USB-C) and it’s run strong on 3 different systems for over a month. Logitech claims a 70-day battery life and they may not have been exaggerating. I wish I could tell for sure how much battery life is remaining, but there are no battery indicators so far as I can tell.Pros:- Beautifully designed mouse with a robust feature-set and cross-OS useability- Superb battery life. Day 33 and this mouse is still going strong. I also appreciate having USB-C charging. Manufacturers need to universally adopt USB-C as the standard for charging and syncing devices today.- Works on all types of surfaces from wood to glass with no issues.- Can connect via Bluetooth and 2.4Ghz adapter; useful for devices that may not have Bluetooth built-inCons:- Not designed for lefties. As a southpaw, I was bothered that this mouse makes no pretenses about being designed exclusively for right-handed customers. We lefties have to adapt to something that isn’t made for us.- Could be related to my being a lefty trying to adjust to a right-handed mouse but I kept inadvertently clicking the forward and back buttons on this mouse. Seems innocent, but if you’re typing a document within a web browser that content can/will be lost.- High FPS gamers may be left out in the cold with this mouse. At this price point, Logitech shouldn’t exclude any demographic who’d want to use their product.Overall, I think this is the finest general purpose mouse on the market. Users can go from business and productivity work to creative designs without issue. This mouse even works on multiple OS’s with quick access to file transfers for open systems even if they’re not using the same operating system. Lefties and gamers may lose some comfort and convenience, but I think all but the most ardent within these sub-groups will find a way to be perfectly satisfied with the MX Master 3 Mouse. Highly recommended to most users.

Scroll wheel does not detect scrolls for roughly a second immediately after lifting the mouse or placing it down. sent this to support but all they could do is send a replacement mouse which had the same issue. Don’t get this mouse if you plan to use it for a bit of a gaming along side productivity.

All of my previous mouse' have been between $15 and $30. So buying a $100 mouse was quite a gift to myself. I decided, one, if I didn't like it, I can return it. And if it encouraged me be more productive, then it's worth every penny.It was super easy to pair. And it has stayed connected to my two devices with ease. The bottom of the mouse has a button, you press once to move to one of three allowed devices. Hold it to pair between the three.You need to download the Logitech Options app from the Logitech website to change button functionality. Most options are available there from using the side wheel to change computer volume, to opening website tabs using specific buttons. There are 7 clickable buttons including the top scroll wheel. The side wheel does not click in as a button.The scroll wheel on the top can either scroll with small notches or completely smooth. This can be varied by the middle top button by default. I like the small notches. If you scroll on the wheel too quickly though, it will automatically spin smooth until you stop it. I just wish websites and other items that scroll can handle how fast the wheel can. I find it gets stuck as it loads.Most applications are represented in the Logitech Options program. And you can program each mouse button to operate a different function in each app. From Photoshop, to Final Cut Pro, to Google Chrome. Each button on my mouse functions a different item in each program. Final Cut the side wheel scrolls the timeline, while the top button deletes a clip. In Google Chrome, the side scroll operates volume and top button opens a new tab. This function has easily found it's way into my daily tasks. Not sure I would know how to use a normal mouse now...The mouse is larger than my previous ones, I'm hoping it will travel okay. It does fit my medium sized hands better than the travel version MX Anywhere.The Flow function (which allows the mouse to slide onto another computer that's next to each other) was a little hard to set up and I found it to be a little laggy. It seems like I'm better off just clicking the bottom button to switch between my iMac and Macbook Pro. I was also a little concerned that the mouse was bluetooth and that it would be laggy when editing on Final Cut or Photoshop - which hasn't been the case at all. Very smooth. I did however use the dongle to see if that would potentially be even better, but I found it lagged more with the dongle, maybe due to both bluetooth and dongle being on. I plan to just leave it on bluetooth if possible.I've had the mouse for three weeks and only charged it when I first got it. I edit on final cut from home so it gets a lot of use.Overall, I'm extremely happy with it. It is a lot a more clicky than I would choose, but definitely a small problem in the scope of how great this mouse is. For the list people, I'll list my pros and cons if you didn't read the rest.Pros:Programmable buttonsAmazing battery lifeEase of connectionErgonomic and fits the hand wellLooks attractiveYou can load the programmed buttons to your other paired device to keep with consistency between devicesCons:It's a bit expensive for a normal mouse (worth the price)Clicky right/left buttonsA bit on the bigger side, but thats more preference/travel issueNo dongle store slot in the bottomA hair on the heavy sideAll in all, an exceptional mouse in its class that has no rivals. Best mouse I've used. Worth the money. If you use a mouse daily/hourly/minutely, this is worth the look.Bonus Review: MX Keys4 out of 5I also bought the MX Keys with it. Great keyboard. A little on the ordinary side for $100.Too heavy and large to travel with, so will be in my home office.Backlit keys are nice, but wish light didn't bleed out around the corners of the keys/but this seems normal. Can easily pair between three devices. The only buttons programmable are the f buttons at the top that already control major computer items. I wish more buttons were programmable like the number keys on the side.I do like having the numbers on the side which I thought I wouldn't. However, it would be nice in photoshop to change those buttons to control brushes, etc.Not sure about battery life, I've only used the keyboard for about a week, but haven't had to charge yet. I'm on my computer hourly.Pros:Heavy, solid keyboard with nice travel on keysNice slant (however it cannot be changed to fit your needs)Backlit keysSnapshot and calculator buttonsProgrammable f buttonsAttractive with the MX Master 3Cons:A tad expensiveA hair too long due to the number keys, but not unmanageableOnly top row of buttons are programmableMX Keys is a solid, well crafted keyboard that pairs great with the MX Master 3. The coloring is attractive and its low profile along with offering nice travel for the keys and comfort with the key grooves is a huge plus. I spent about $200 on it, but found a coupon code for 10% off LOGITECHSAVE10 when buying at Logitech.Both are worth buying. Both are amazing products and I know that if you spend the money, you won't regret it.
This mouse is wonderful. Cant ask for more. Very good for productivity. We can do application specific gestures using the mouse.

There is no question the placement of the back and forward buttons has been improved as well as the horizontal scrolling wheel. The tracking also seems more precise. The gesture button is also vastly improved and now has an actual physical button.  Before there was nothing.However, the deal breaker for me is the shape of the mouse.  On the MX Master, I can rest my 2nd and 3rd fingers on the mouse buttons, which have a glossy finish. There is very little effort involved in clicking the buttons.  The MX3 has a lower profile than the MX Master. The shape has been radically changed. On the MX3 there is a gap between where my fingers sit and the mouse buttons. My fingers no longer rest on the mouse buttons.  The  physical mouse buttons on the MX Master, besides sitting higher, are about 5/8" cm longer in length and that also makes a perceptible difference. The MX buttons are also a bit wider, which makes them easier to press.  Essentially, it's more fatiguing to my 2nd and 3rd fingers to hold them just above the buttons on the MX3. The surface of the MX3 mouse buttons is also matte which creates a bit more friction. The angle of the buttons is also different. The bottom line is that MX3, while sleeker and more polished in design,  is much less comfortable (to me) and requires more effort and dexterity to use. Those with different size hands might find their results are different from mine. I'm also 67 and might not have the same dexterity and strength as a younger person. The ergonomics are just not there for me.

It's excellent in all its features, it's a bit pricey but if it lasts, I won't have buyer's remorse.I would have rather had a replacement for my G700s but this is growing on me. The battery is by far better than the G700s and I'm getting used to the button arrangement. I used the tilt scroll wheel to scroll horizontally on the G700s but I'm finding the side scroll on the MX3 is just as good. The scroll wheel itself is faster and smoother which is another plus. There was more programmability for each button on the G700s and I'm hoping that's going to improve in the software for the MX3

This mouse is the best one I have used so far.  Very superficial for the wrist. Electromagnetic scroll wheel allows for precise or freewheeling motion. Downloadable profiles for popular apps. Works across up to three devices, and even between OSs. Great battery life.

The MX 3 mouse by Logitech looks and works great!  As with MX Keys keyboard the link printed on box to acquire needed drivers is inaccurate and you need to search on web for the correct link.  Battery life is superior!  Works on any surface I’ve tried.  Very comfortable for larger hands with long fingers.

I ordered this for my husband, an electrical engineer who designs stuff at work using two computers at a time. Oddly, he never even took it to work. He tried it out at home and decreed it "bulky" and heavy. I've commandeered this mouse, which is capable of so much more than I'll ever be capable of, myself, which makes me feel guilty for failing to utilize such a nice bit of tech. Then I remember how little I have ever utilized my computer, phone, even my Kindle, which can do so many things I've never tried to get it do. So, this wireless mouse (rechargable; no batteries; no long cord tangled at the side of my pc) is like a Jaguar that I drive as if it were a1978 Oldsmobile. Ah, the wasted opportunities. But it's a nice, smooth ride, and I like it.

I ordered on Sept 10th, didn't arrive until Sept 30th, annoying but it happens. I try to turn it on and nothing happens. Maybe it needs to charge so I plug it in and wait. Still nothing after messing with it over the days, DOA. Now I have to ship it back which is a massive pain. The replacement won't ship until November! I want to like this mouse and it feels nice in the hand but this situation sucks.

I've been mostly using gaming mice the last several years, even for normal work and Logitech is currently my favorite brand for lightweight, quality, and reliability. I've heard so many great things about the MX Master mouse and was curious to try it. I will say right off the bat that I was and am very impressed with this mouse. It is comfortable to use, extremely accurate, works on any surface including a glass desk, and the battery lasts about a month before needing a charge. Those features are great but the main thing that keeps me using this mouse over my other ones is the scroll wheel and the gesture feature which is programmable. The side scroll wheel is also very high quality and can be programmed on a per application basis which is just fantastic.For users of the previous MX Master, this has a lot of similar features but the most noticeable to me are the side buttons, which are laid out more like a traditional gaming mouse and not crammed on top of each other like the previous models. I actually tried using this for gaming and aside from being a bit heavy, it works very well. I wouldn't recommend this primarily as a gaming mouse but for someone who plays occasionally, this one works fine and there's no need to buy a separate mouse, although I would recommend a mouse pad for gaming.Aside from the build quality, the way it feels, and all the thoughtful features, I like the modern additions on this mouse. I have so many wireless mice and this is the only one with a USB-C port. No wireless charging on this model but due to the long battery life, it's really not needed. Just charge it once a month (they claim a battery life of 70 days but I have a reminder set to charge it at the end of each month to be consistent). If you do run the battery all the way down, one minute of charging will last 3 hours. Another interesting feature of this mouse is the ability to pair it to 3 different computers via Bluetooth by flipping a switch on the bottom and it works great on both OSX or Windows 10. I did not have a chance to test on Linux. I don't use the Bluetooth feature, I prefer to use the dongle. It's absolutely not needed if you use Bluetooth, but I prefer the dongle because it's just a bit faster and if you use this mouse for gaming at all, you will notice a difference in response time.If I had to list one reason why I'm giving this mouse 5 stars, it's the scroll wheel. It really is incredible and hard to explain in a review. You can go from scrolling one line or pixel at a time to flying down a long document. It's really incredible and by far the best feature of this mouse and the best scroll wheel I've ever used. If you are looking for a top productivity mouse for graphic design, coding/development, or just want a really nice mouse - this is the one I'm going to recommend. It's not cheap but you can really feel the quality as soon as you put your hand on it.
The mouse is thinner as a result your pinky finger and ring finger are just hanging instead of resting on the mouse 2 and 1 were better.

This is a great upgrade mouse for anyone who codes or develops all day long. I love all the customizations you can do to the buttons, and make them specific to different applications. It is a little on the pricey side, but there are so many additional features, I think it makes it worth it.Pros: • Easy to setup - worked with the receiver on my work computer straight away. • Could connect to either USB receiver or Bluetooth  • Can stay connected to three computers at the same time  • Can be used on nearly any surface, even glass • Rechargeable integrated battery with USB-C. (Though don't expect to use the USB-C cable that comes with other devices - only the one that came with the mouse worked to charge it). • Can set up unique uses of all the extra buttons for just about any application you have. The ability to customize by application makes this mouse really special. You can even put keyboard shortcuts onto buttons. Imagine you have a VBA macro in Excel mapped to a keyboard shortcut. You can trigger the shortcut with a single button click.Cons: • The extra features like the scroll wheel required me to download the Logitech options application, which required me to setup an account. I understand the need for the app if you want to change from the default settings, but I don't know why it wouldn't come shipped with the defaults loaded. (I'm guessing to grab some email addresses). • Since the customizations only work on the computer where the app is installed, if you have an Enterprise workstation where you can't install just any application, you might not be able to use all the customizations on your work computer. • It would be great if it came with a hard shell case to offer some protection.Overall, the pros far exceed the cons with this mouse. There are so many customizations you can do with this - the possibilities are endless.

Sadly after all these years, the MX Revolution is still the best mouse ever made. I also appreciate the click button responsiveness of the Performance MX mouse. The MX Master series (1,2 and now 3) all have click buttons that are not springy/clicky/responsive (however you want to put it) enough. After about an hour of use, the click buttons become mushy, in that the don't travel and rebound well enough to make using it a snappy and enjoyable experience. Cheap parts? Inability to listen to customer feedback?  I don't know. I'm just disappointed. If anybody knows a workaround to make the click buttons more responsive, I'd love to hear it.

An absolute joy to use. Wireless performs flawlessly. Keybindings are excellent. Mouse has kept charge for 4 days under gaming sessions & research applications. Exceptionally comfortable while using palm OR claw grip. Both scroll wheels are the best i've touched so far. Worth every penny , and better than most high end gaming mice costing twice as much.

I have been using this mouse for the past four days.  I was eager to test out this mouse because I love my Logitech keyboard (the G815), even though I was already using a precise gaming mouse (the Viper Razer).The MX Master 3 is wireless, but it needs to charge via a usb cable.  According to the info sheet included with the mouse, a 3 minute charge will keep the mouse running for a full day, and a day of charging will run the mouse for up to 70 days.  I charged it for 10 minutes before using it the first day, and have had it charging at night while we sleep the past two nights.  The mouse has been going strong and has not had any power issues.The mouse connects to the computer with a small usb receiver.  I put it in one of the front ports of the computer because it was easier than fully swapping the mice.  My Razer is still connected, but is tucked away beside the tower.Shape-wise, this is the most comfortable and hand-conforming mouse that I have had in my hand.  It is just a bit too large and high off of the mouse pad to be comfortable for my smaller hand to use for hours on end.  I am 5'3" and wear women's small to medium gloves.  If you have larger hands, this will probably not be an issue for you.  A wrist pad would also help, but that won't work with my desk layout.The scroll wheel is very sensitive and I love it.  The movement is responsive and precise, just as precise as my Razer, but way more precise than a cheapo ball mouse or an inexpensive optic mouse.The mouse is very easy to install and set up.  I was using the mouse within minutes of charging it.  It is customizable with Logitech software.I will be switching back to my Razer, but only because it fits better in my little hands for long periods of use.  If they made a smaller version of this mouse for smaller handed people, I'd be all over it.

I really don't have any complaints other than the price, but I paid it and I think it was worth it so far.Update: ok, I do have one complaint. There is no place in the mouse to store the receiver. The fact that it also uses bluetooth prevents me from deducting a star, but I am afraid I will lose the receiver.
Very disappointed, he mouse can even compared with the Apple Magic Mouse. The scroll is lagging and jittering. Do try it if you want to use with Mac.

I upgraded to the MX Master 3 from a Logitech M510, and am very happy with it so far. It has a unique look for a mouse, but it's very comfortable to hold. The size is just right, and it feels ergonomically-friendly. Vertical scrolling is super smooth, which is a big difference from my previous mouse. The thumb wheel on the side helps navigate wide documents and spreadsheets.I use a mouse for things like photo editing, text editing, and gaming, so I’m finding all the extra features very useful. For those who want to get into specific customization, the Logitech Options software lets you tweak the scrolling speed, direction, sensitivity, etc. There are many more options than any mouse I've had so far. It also allows you to copy text from one computer and paste it on another, which is a cool feature.As far as compatibility, the MX Master 3 can work with three different computers. I’m using it with two: a Windows and a Mac. Switching back and forth is very easy. There’s a little button on the bottom to switch between computers. It also works with Linux.It connects via a small plug-in USB receiver or via Bluetooth. Those with newer Macs that have only the USB-C slots will need to connect via Bluetooth or use a USB adapter.This mouse has been great so far, and I’ve had no trouble with it. It's accurate, feels well-made, and makes working on the computer much easier for me.

I have the MX Master 2S and loved everything about that mouse except for the placement of the thumb forward back web browser buttons. Overlapping them means you never click the right one.The MX Master 3 finally separated the buttons so you can distinguish with feel quicker which one you want. The design is slightly different so I will need to get used to it after using the 2S for 2 years....no big deal as its just as comfortable.It's a very precise mouse just like its predecessor. I think the click is more solid and also slightly quieter... I don't know why companies still make the click sound....i kind of feel it's not necessary anymore. Especially if you are click happy like myself.You can customize buttons as needed like other previous models. I have mine hooked up via bluetooth on a mac. You do need to use your old mouse to set things up first as the new mouse isn't connected yet, unless you use the usb plug, then its connectedRecharging is easy with the usb/c connector. I wish that it was usb-c on both sides or at least an adapter included because when i get my new mac i'll now have to get an adapter or unplug usb 3 plugs to recharge. However, it is way easier to recharge as the old usb mini was such a pain to plug into the mouse.Only wish it came in colors too...my fav is blue but maybe in the future?

I love so muchit is well designed every single partslove to using infinity skroll wheel Some review complain about back and forth button, but it is just good for me and it is much better than 2sand it dose shiped very quickly even in korea, takes 1 weaks

I have the former MX Master 2S and upgraded to the 3. All seems fine except the scrolling with the scroll wheel. After about 3 turns of the wheel the web pages don't scroll consistently (tried multiple browsers) as if the wheel turning is not being detected internally properly. I tried the same with the 2S again and no scroll issues so something is definitely wrong with this mouse. Put in for a defective item replacement and hope it's just this one mouse. Will update this review if the replacement fixes the problem.Edit: I forgot to mention that I bought this updated MX Master 3 hoping the macOS bluetooth jittery cursor issues would be fixed as there are known bluetooth problems with macOS with the MX Master 2S. Sadly they were not fixed and it's still jittery on a Mac.

Hands down, the best mouse I've ever used.  I've used standard mice, ergonomic mice, and trackballs, but none of them compare to the comfort of this mouse.  The shape is ergonomic but more familiar to the hand, so you get the benefit without the awkward adjustment period.  The two scroll wheels (yes, two!) seem like they should have been done years ago.  They naturally scroll as you'd expect (one by top goes up and down while the one on the side goes side to side, wow!) but you can also push the top one and zoom around also.  With the two other buttons on the side and one on the bottom under your thumb, you almost never need to take your hand off the mouse to move around web pages or switch applications.  The software (188MB download, yikes!!) lets you do more customizations, including some nifty features in MS Office applications.  As good as all this is, my favorite part is the sensor.  My desktop is high gloss so most mice just get lost, forcing me to buy a new mouse pad every year or so.  No more!  Not only does this work, it works well!  I really can't say enough good things about this mouse (rechargeable battery, hello!).  It's my new best friend!

9/29/19 Update: This mouse doesn't scroll in Calendar on the Mac. I sent an email to an address that was on a separate piece of paper that said it would be sent directly to the marketing director. But I received a response obviously from an outsourced support person who didn't appear to read my email but sent a scripted response asking for information that I had already sent. Unfortunately, support appears to be a long and tedious process if there is any.------------------------------------------------------------------------While I liked the size and shape of the mouse that came with my iMac plus swiping across the top to switch desktops, etc I always had a problem with getting it to click left or right, at least half of the time it would do the opposite even when I consciously place my fingers correctly. I got to where I hated the Apple mouse. This one is a decent replacement as long as you install additional software that is required to be downloaded from Logitech website not the App Store.Button placement is great and of course separate so that I know when I click left or right.While there is no swipe pad you can, after installing the software and letting it access settings, customize all of the buttons and rollers on the mouse. So I use the roller on the side to switch desktops.It is huge in comparison to the Apple mouse but I do like the shape and feel in my hand. But there is one tiny button right under your thumb that is hard to press so I set it to a seldom used function like accessing the desktop list at the top of the screen.You can also use this with up to three computers and literally swipe between them or press a button on the bottom of the mouse to use it with a different computer which works really well.And, where Apple really failed, you can charge this while you use it!Overall, I like this mouse as a replacement for the Apple mouse.
Full recommendation.

I've had the mx master 2s for over a year and loved it so wanted to upgrade to the mx Master 3 when I saw it come out. It connect to my computer fine, but I have tried for the last hour to get the options software to recognize my new mx master 3 but it won't work. Other than that, really great mouse. Will update rating to 5 stars if the software gets fixed.

The scroll wheel is awesome. The fit and finish is awesome though it should have a model slippery rubber coating when I can get around that problem. The buttons are decent enough. The scroll wheel is awesome. But......Damn it damn it damn it. How many times is it going to take for you to get the damned forward and back buttons right!Version one sucked. Version 2 sucked. Version 3 walad admittedly slightly improved, STILL STUCK!They are too small , too stiff, and meld in to everything around them.They need to be made much larger and they need to be place much lower.Oh well. Maybe version 4 will get them right...TWO stars off for little or no useability testing with REAL customers instead of devs and managers.Damn it.

This is my first MX Master mouse. I plan to use it for my 3d design work, and so far I think it will definitely hold up well. Here are some pros and cons I've observed in my first 24 hours using it. First of all, I absolutely love the scroll wheel. It is quiet, smooth, and very satisfying. I suggest turning up the "Smartshift Sensitivity" in the Logitech Options software. That reduces how easily the ratcheting wheel switches to free scrolling. I have it all the way up to like 85%. With this change, it is much more intuitive feeling for me. The laser works great on all surfaces I've tried so far. Bluetooth connection is very responsive, but I had to turn off a setting on my laptop that was putting the bluetooth receiver to sleep after like 3 seconds of inactivity. My complaints are that the gesture button location feels just out of natural reach. I also don't love the grip of it yet, the palm section of the mouse comes out very far which encourages a slightly more vertical grip. I know this is good for me so I'll try to embrace it, but I'm sure it will take some getting used to. All in all it seems like it will be a great mouse.
WHY Logitech!  Why? Lets finally go FULL USB C not this half butt effort. I want to see a full butt USB C effort.

The MX Master 2s was a fantastic mouse, but I had two complaints about it: 1, It used Micro USB instead of Type C and 2, the thumb wheel and navigation buttons were hard to use.The MX Master 3 fixes both those problems. The thumb wheel now has a very high quality feel to it and is very easy to spin around, and they've moved the navigation buttons lower down to make them easier to press with your thumb. The main scrollwheel has also been made quieter, and somehow even more fun to use.As before, this mouse works on pretty much all surfaces, can connect to 3 devices, and can connect by either bluetooth or a USB dongle. I've had no issues using it on both a Mac and PC.Logitech claims a battery life of 70 days, and while I obviously haven't been able to test that out yet, if the MX Master 2S is anything to go by, you can expect great battery life on this mouse too.
a bit heavy for gaming but perfect for me otherwise for wfh

The arthritis in my hand was being exasperated  by my mouse, After research I settled on the Logitech mouse and I'm not disappoed! It has a comfort level I quickly learned to appreciate. It's a pleasure to use.

I have been using the g502 for productivity/gaming for years. I was excited to use this mouse. But for mac you do notice a lot of lag. It bothers me. For some it may not be an issue. I feel for the price there could have been more customization and buttons. I would definitely recommend the g502 over this guy.  I personally had a lot of shortcuts programmed into the g502.Ps the touch features are not great. The ergonomics of pressing the button with your thumb is not ideal.Other than the above it’s a great mouse.
This product has an amazing design and feel to it. It is probably the one thing that makes me want to come home and do work instead of staying at school like I usually do.

I already owned the MX Master mouse, and I thought I was adding the same mouse. The upgrade to the feel of the button click is the best thing about this mouse. This is a superbly built mouse with quality components. The scroll buttons are solid and comfortable. The Logi Plus customization is mind-boggling. I especially love the satisfying thumb button that I use for deleting emails. It is a satisfying click of the mouse. This is the Bentley of mice.

I've owned my Master MX (1) mouse for 15 years, so it was logical to replace it with it's younger brother.Excellent battery life and amazingly fast charging through the USB-C port.Very ergonomic and comfortable to use, although I suspect that the "rubberized" coating will wear off after a few years, like it did on my MX1 mouse.

Thought, "Why not spend good money on a keyboard/mouse combo as I sit in front of the computer all day."  Well this turned out to be a sad story and a keyboard and mouse in the garbage.  Oh well!  Live and learn.  I shall not be giving any further cask to Logitech.  Everything started stuttering and not connecting well, and I can not abide a keyboard and mouse which are not dependable.  Good money wasted and life-long customer lost Logitech.  I am sad to put you behind me but dependability is key!

A premium feeling and performing mouse for non-gamers and professionals. High quality materials, premium feeling touch points including a soft-touch palm and thumb rest, metal scroll wheels and extremely quiet buttons. Scroll wheel can be toggled between notched and free spinning, 2 programmable side bottoms, a programmable side scroll wheel, and a programmable gesture button on the bottom of the thumb rest. Setup on my Surface Pro was non-existent. Turned it on for the first time and it was automatically synced to my device via Bluetooth. Can also be synced to 2 other devices and easily switched been them with a button on the bottom. Highly recommend.
Great mouse for ergonomics and productivity while working.
Very pleased with this mouse. SUPER quiet clicks, lots of buttons, and side-scrolling  wheel is GREAT for my Excel work. Great hand-feel and fit.
Easy to use for MAC and Windows. Multiple connection on various device.

I love the feel and shape of this mouse. Not too loud. EVerything works fine. Works better than the MX keyboard, it seems, because it loses connection much less often. It is too heavy, slow, and inaccurate for gaming, though.
It's great, a fantastic mouse but I bought a white one and one Cheeto mistake and it's permanently disgusting.Never buy a white mouse omg. Otherwise it's a really good mouse.

At first, I liked it but over time you get annoyed on having to turn on and off the device so it will connect properly again. Then after months of using it, the thumb button is not working properly.  Logitech help please!!!!
The patent of the scroll rolling was amazing

I did not know the grey color of this mouse can stain this bad. Just a few days of usage and you can clearly see horrible stains on the mouse. I keep my work space clean and regularly clean my hands and surfaces, but even with that, the discoloration is evident. I'd recommend getting the black color of this mouse as Amazon does not replace the mouse with a different color.
One of the most expensive mouse on the market that costs $130, starts getting yellowish after one month of use.
Love the ability to seamlessly transition between up to 3 devices (via Bluetooth) with the click of a button. Battery life is excellent. My favorite mouse to-date.

A small change like silent clicking can make a huge difference. The ability to custom program side scroll buttons to zoom in and out in InDesign, MS word/Power Point is an awesome feature. Great product.
Nice updates over version 2 make this the best mouse on the market.  Great ergos and high resolution make it a weapon for all day use.
you get for what you pay for. quality should always be in the forefront

I ordered this mouse with high expectations due to the high price & build quality, but the scroll wheel was very disappointing. The scrolling is INCREDIBLY inconsistent & horribly inaccurate compared to what they advertise. It's like spinning your tires in a racecar before actually starting to move... sometimes it doesn't even respond. Also, the magnetic system beneath the scroll wheel lags behind your scroll movements, creating a thumping sound/feeling in the mouse and even more issues when scrolling quickly. For reference, I used another bluetooth Logitech mouse at work (probably $40-$50) and the scrolling was 100% accurate.There should be no scrolling issues for such an expensive mouse... but there are!

I've been using an MX 2 for both productivity and gaming for several years, and wanted to upgrade to the latest version. The MX 3S is a nice fit for large hands, and shows no appreciable latency lag. I don't care about the vaunted silent button click, since I usually wear ANC headphones.
However, it does not come with any instructions to indicate you need to go to the Logitech site to download the software to customise it and use all the features and customize the buttons and functions.Also, Logitech does not provide its control apps (Options and Options+) to the Microsoft store, only as download on its own site. This means these mice don't work well on Windows S-mode devices, since they can only run apps from the Microsoft store. The mice will function as basic, non-customizable devices in S mode, but features like the variable scroll wheel, and thumb wheel won't function without Options (or Options+). If you use an S-mode device, look for a less-expensive, basic mouse until Logitech makes Options+ available on the Microsoft store.

Excellent work mouse. Very comfortable to use for long work sessions

This mouse has a lot of good features to it. I like the thumb rest button and the infinite scroll wheel the most, also being able to reprogram the buttons for different applications is really useful.I have only used the wireless dongle for the mouse, I do not have Bluetooth on my computer to test that connectivity out. The wireless dongle works very well, I haven't seen any slow response or disconnects. It does support 3 devices on Bluetooth but I haven't used the feature to see how well it works. Also you can't switch devices easily from just the mouse controls itself, you have to press the button underneath the mouse to switch to another device.I've been using it for a week now and have not had to charge it since the first charge. There is no easy way to check the charge of the mouse, you have to open the Logi options software to view its charge level. I'll have to try it in Bluetooth mode to see if it shows a charge in Windows.The only gripe I have for it is that, I have smaller hands and the mouse is quite large, I'm not able to reach all the buttons unless I adjust my hand placement each time. Due to this it's not a great mouse for gaming where you would need quick access to all the buttons on the mouse.I do wish that they had an ambidextrous version that could add more buttons, so that I could program more specific macros to them.Overall the mouse is great for productivity tasks and office applications, it is okay for gaming depending on the game you're playing, it's good for non competitive single player games, I wouldn't suggest it for competitive games that need precise actions. The wireless worked seamlessly and the software it comes with allows you to program different button actions depending on the application you're using.

This mouse is retailed at $125.You purchase it then you get stuck in the world of Logitech compatibility issues.Like me, if you are looking to purchase the MX Master Mini keyboard ($115-125), make sure you scour the web for the MX Master 3 Professional mouse become the MX Master 3 I purchased at the end of 2021 (DEC) does not support the new Logi Bolt usb.And don’t be alarmed if once you do finally find this newer MX Master 3 Professional that the new Logi Bolt unifying receiver is not included and you will need to shell out another $25 dollars for that.So after approximately ~$275 or so dollars, time wasted trying to figure out why the damn things are no sinking together. Send back the Keyboard if you ended up purchasing it.Realizing this company is using slick promotion realizing they have two of the same products on the market with just a small tiny logo on the bottom of it.All that to say .. it is a superb mouse!! Probably the last one you’ll want to use, baring the semi Bluetooth drops.. but due to the ergonomics (fits my hand perfectly). I also have the G502 Hero for gaming; that was a year previous purchase and only reason why I gave the MX Master 3 a look after raving reviews from previous iteration owners.Great mouse.. but last investment put into Logitech! Sneaky advertising is just poor business practice!To this day they’re still swindling people on their site.You’ll love the mouse! Not the manufacturer!! And they don’t care!!!5 stars for the mouse itseft! A minus infinity to the company!

As compared to my previous MX Anywhere this definitely an upgrade.I use it mostly with design softwares like Sketch and Figma on a Mac.The good:- Works with Bluetooth right out of the box.- Set up is mostly straight forward- Customization options are also easy to configure.- The smart scroll is a bit weird at first but once you get used to it it's kinda nice for those extra long scrolls.- I like the ergonomics. My hand position doesn't feel weird and for my smallish hands it is a good fit.- There are a lot more Mac friendly gestures and buttons right out the box.- Easy to connect to multiple devices and switch between them.The button on the base is slightly difficult to get used to but the second scroll wheel is easy to use.The bad:- Logi Options software needs a restart before it can start recognising your mouse.- The scroll would suddenly stop working. When this happes just go into your Mac Accessibility Settings and allow Logi Options in the list along with Logi Daemon.- This was particularly bad since scroll is the most used feature and you wouldn't think of such a thing to happen.Otherwise it is a solid mouse for a variety of work flows. I haven't gamed with it but I am sure there are much better gaming mice that Logitech offers.

This is a combined review for Logitech MX Keys and MX Master 3 mouse. I purchased them together.I have an iMac 5K and Windows Laptop with 27" monitor. I was struggling (for space) with two KBs and two mice. So while looking for the solution, I found the perfect answer - the MX combo. I read about the duo. These are fairly expensive but they have significantly increased my productivity. I have connected to both systems via BlueTooth (we can use the dongles also). Now I can simply move my mouse across and seamlessly connect to Mac or Windows and the KB too connects across. The two behave like two bodies and one soul! I can copy/paste across two systems as diverse as Mac and Windows. I have a provision to connect to a third system. Having freed the clutter on the desk has made my life so much easy. The desk looks clean also and of course, there are no wires.The KB is solid aluminium and does not feel cheap. To date, I was using plastic keyboards. While they are not bad, this KB takes me to a different realm. The keys are illuminated and activated by the hand motion sensor. The keys are low profile - so some who like mechanical keys and long travel keystrokes may not like this. I prefer this way.The mouse is so easy on the hand and is possibly the best in business. It has programmable keys and I can have keys specific to Word, Excel, Photoshop, etc. The scrolling is smooth. There is normal vertical scrolling, superfast vertical scrolling. I have horizontal thumb scrolling and a tiny recessed button to save (below the thumb). I have read some negative feedback on the system switch button (1-2-3) at the mouse bottom and being inconvenient but let me assure you that if Logi Options software is installed, the flow from one desktop to another is just by moving the mouse. It can be further restricted by having to press the control key to prevent accidental movement to next desktop screen.Finally, both the devices can be charged by a cable and it connects by USB-C port on the devices. I am told that a single charge is sufficient to last over two months. Let's see. I used to own the first MX Master Mouse and if it has one flaw it was the charging dock. Over time, the gold plated contacts wore off and the mouse became a paperweight. This has been corrected by a sturdier USB charging port.In summary, I will highly recommend this, especially to those having multiple systems. But even if you have a single system, you cannot go wrong - except maybe your pockets will become shallower.  For this, I am docking off one point for VFM. Since I do not play games (not that I am against gaming), I am unable to comment on that aspect.p/s. I also purchased the desk mat that is seen in the pic. It enhances the desk and makes it look really good.

I’ve been using another brands vertical mouse the past year, but the movement isn’t very fluid and based on all the reviews of the Mx master 3, I thought it would be good to get for work.  As others have said, it is rather large, my hands aren’t small, but this thing really feels oddly shaped in them.Also, the ergonomics of it is poor, I could feel the pull in my wrist as I used it.  The scroll wheels are nice, but they didn’t seem as fluid as I’d hoped.I’m sure it’s a great mouse for some, but just not for me.  I think I’ll go with the mx vertical.
Hight quality  and excellent  look  worth every  penny
This is so fast the best mouse I ever had. Precise and smooth and can shift from my laptop to IPad with just a touch.

I’m so surprised on how quickly the delivery service was!Believe I placed the order on late evening around 9pm and received next morning before 10am.Of course the logitech product quality and functionsare always top and very happy with the simple and ease of pairing to my Mac.Highly recommended to anyone looking for a good mouse.
Nice product!

Overall the mouse has a very premium feel, which, coupled with its perfectly ergonomic shape, makes it very comfortable for prolonged use.
Great mouse, all you need to increase productivity when at the laptop whole day

At first, I really loved this mouse, as far as comfort and precision it works really well. However after around two years the rubber has started to show significant wear, and it looks like I might be replacing it within another 6 months if it continues. Given I've used some of my other Logitech mice for well over 5 years, my MX518 lasting me over 10, I am not very impressed.

Died within a year of use, sad. Bad quality, the mouse wheel lock mechanism broke, and clicking doesn't work half the time. Not even a year of use. Just poor build/part quality. About 8 hours of use a day for work, 5 times a week for the last 7 months. At first I thought it was the drivers, nope, it's the mouse itself. You click somewhere, it doesn't register as a click although you're clicking. Also stops tracking intermittently. The mouse wheel lock mechanism is broken as well, instead of doing the tactile hard scroll it just goes and goes. Tested this on multiple machines.Now, when it actually works, pretty sweet. But, I mean, less than a year and it's dead? Garbo, not going for logitech products after this mouse. It's not an inexpensive product too.

In MacOS, Logitech Options does not detect mouse via Bluetooth therefore the advanced features cannot be used. Need to use the unifying receiver in order to unlock the full potential of this mouse which occupies one USB-C port and requires a dongle. The mouse is ergonomic and almost perfect in other ways.
love the scroll wheels!
I have owned all 3 version of the product over the years. The Master 3 is good incremental improvement. Well worth the money.
This product was bought on the advice of a colleague.Love it.  Very comfortable for my big hands, battery lasts long per charge, and the flexibility of options is truly easy to configure.

Reviewer Name: Doug Taylor, Paralegal Licensee, Commissioner of Oaths and Notary Public

I love mice like this. This is the third time I had to return a new logitech mx master 3. The first one had a scratch out of the box, second one had horizontal scroll wheel issue, and now this third has a loose vertical scroll wheel which can't be modified by logitech flow software. Its sad to see logitech go downhill. FYI I have another mx master 3 I purchased 2 years ago which is still working perfectly fine until today

C'mon - we all know this is way too much to pay for a bloody mouse - but I wanted the best. I really thought I was about to upgrade my computing experience. The Logitech Unifying Device has no drivers for Windows 10 and the operating system is not shy about telling you that. You can connect via bluetooth, but that seems flakey and it drops the connection intermittently but reliably - probably the only reliable quality I've seen in action. This was a waste of time, money, and effort. I'm going with anyone else.

This is my second purchase of the mx master 3 and this time it failed me badly. There’s nothing wrong with the mouse itself. It’s still a fantastic mouse, one of the best I’ve ever used for work. But take a look at the pictures I posted, on what universe will you be able to convince people that this mouse is brand new? All 3 pads have scratches and clear signs of some decent amount of usage already. I’m gonna have to return this one because I think it’s a used one, still gonna give this mouse a 4 star though

Scrolling :
I did not notice it at first but at some point I noticed the scrolling is inconsistent : making the same motion multiple times does not always result in the same scrolling, which is quite annoying. I'm not sure yet if this was just a temporary issue or a common issue. I found a few people having this issue on reddit and I tried changing the mouse settings but it did not help. I tried another wireless mouse (Razer Viper Ultimate) and I don't have this issue.EDIT : it appears to be less apparent on my work laptop, some users think this is related to wireless signal interferencesSize :Despite the mouse being larger than the G502, the grip is smaller (58mm vs 63mm according to rtings). This being said, you can grip the larger base somehow so it offers way larger than 58mm, which you can't do as easily with the G502. This is great (for me) because I think being able to switch to a larger grip makes it easier on the hand : same concept as for a chair, you need to change position to avoid "hurting" your body on the long run.Weight :I tried a few mice recently, the HyperX pulsefire (and cool master mm720) feels the best so far, it's much lighter so it feels effortless to move, it feels easier to be precise. The MX Master 3 is the heaviest I tried and my least favourite. If you want a lighter wireless mouse, I like the Razer Viper Ultimate which you can order with a dock, pretty useful for "wireless charging".Height :The MX Master height is quite high which might encourage you to put your wrist in a more extended position, which does not feel as confortable and is probably worst for the Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. I guess it depends on you end up holding that mouse because there ways to avoid the extended position.DPI :No big deal but you can't set DPI via Logitech Options+, instead you set Pointer Speed. I think it would have been more logical to use the DPI approach like other mice.USB Cable :You can use the mouse while wired, which is nice. This being said, the cable is only used to charge, it can't be used to control the mouse, it only uses wireless so you can't use the mouse without the logitech Unifying usb receiver plugged in your PC and used for wireless. The usb cable is quite short, I found a workaround by pluging it in my keyboard usb port (some monitors also have usb ports).Gestures :It looked like a good idea, as long as you remember all gestures but the only useful gesture I found for me is by setting the "click" opens "This PC".Side wheel :I have keyboard corsair k70 lux rgb which also as a wheel which I integrated with Lightroom using macros in iCue, it works well. I tried doing the same with the Logitech mouse and it worked. So that's a good point (almost the only one?). But I think the best setup for Lightroom is using a MIDI controller, which I have not tried yet.I tried a few workarounds to fix some issues, like a wrist pad to help with the height, and a usb cable extender to help with dongle signal, changing the settings in Logitech Options+.For me the biggest downside is the inconsistent scrolling, it's not that bad but it's quite annoying, I tried 2 MX master 3 and both had this issue.
This is the best mouse I have ever used its very comfy - no wrist pain or anything, very smooth, battery lasts forever. LOVE the middle scroll clicking.
class="cr-original-review-content">Fonctionne très bien pour le dessin

This is probably the best "professional" mouse. I could not find a competing mouse with the same features, and they all work well.The hardware is great.* It feels high quality.* It has soft in places where you grip it, then hard materials where you click (soft materials just wear out).* It moves as smoothly as any other mouse I've had.* It has a horizontal scroll wheel!!!* The gesture button works very well. I was prepared for this to feel like a gimmick, but it is legitimately useful.* Being able to pair with 3 devices is great.Flaws:* I use a fingertip grip with mice. The place where my pinky grips is starting to wear a bit. It so far hasn't worn thru the soft plastic, which does imply a thicker coating than many mice get.* If you palm the mouse, it is probably a bit small. The gesture button would be hard to hit.* Sometimes when I pick up the mouse to hit the button that switches devices, and it just does nothing. Flicking the power switch always resolves this.* Being able to remap buttons on an app-by-app basics is fantastic.Those are pretty minor complaints for the hardware. Mouse mice are much worse.The real criticisms are with the software.* While this is a professional product, the software package looks like it was designed by the gaming department. It is as tacky looking as software could look.* The default settings for the mouse are terrible. The pointer speed, scrolling speed, and mappings for the gesture button are all weird. It even has some app specific settings that are bad (it defaults the horizontal scroll wheel to "change tab" for web browsers. Web browsers are one of few apps where horizontal scrolling is a thing...). This is only a problem because:* Sometimes when the mouse wakes up or swaps devices, it won't load your settings for that device. The only way I've found to deal with this situation is to reboot the device. This happens on average twice a week.* If you don't use their suggested settings for an app, it will show a notification in the top right of the settings app.* None of the slider bars have tick marks or show the numeric value. This makes it fiddly to manually copy settings from device to device.* Logitech probably justifies this by saying to use their syncing system, but it is blocked by my work VPN so it is a non option. Also the privacy policy they make you agree to is awful. I'd break my work's security policies if I agreed to it, which is probably why they blocked the server.* The maximum horizontal wheel speed is quite low. The wheel doesn't spin freely, which is probably meant to prevent unintended scrolling, but the software should allow setting it higher. The highest setting for the horizontal wheel is about the same as the lowest setting for the vertical wheel.* The battery level only shows 3 levels: high, medium, and low. Even cheap mice show a percentage.* Some of the options for the gesture button work by simulating keyboard presses. This means you can't change the key binding. Other mice I've used by Razor can invoke these functions directly, which allows changing the key binding.
Really nice shape and comfortable. Battery is long lasting.

Bought to accompany the great MX Keys. Although the mouse looks great and feels nice in the hand, scrolling just doesn't work if you make quick movements on the wheel. If you navigate up and down by making short, quick flicking scrolls, then you will hate this mouse - the page either stays in place or scrolls by one or two units with each flick, rather than with unit pip per detent you feel (which is how every other mouse works). The horizontal scrolling never seemed to work right either even after installing the logitech software.
Ergonomic mouse, saved my arm and wrist from developing carpal tunnel

Let me start off by saying that I am NOT gaming with this mouse. I use it in my day to day work, in programming and some 3D design which relies quite heavily on the middle button/ scroll wheel.If you start reading around online, without a doubt the issues you are likely to see most often are surrounding the scroll wheel. There are two problems I found come up quite often: connectivity and behavior. I use this mouse with a MacBook Pro over bluetooth, and at first I found the scrolling a bit inconsistent and occasionally after my laptop had gone to sleep, the mouse would work except the scroll wheel. Turning it off and on was not helping.Finally, (MacOS) I found that going into my System Settings > Security & Privacy > Accessibility and enabling the setup software 'Logi Options', fixed the issues for me - especially the scroll wheel being disabled after the laptop went to sleep.While it is not going to be a silver bullet for everyone, I attached my current settings in Logi Options. I find that most of the time I have the ratcheting disabled on my scroll wheel, and when I need more precise smaller increments I enable the ratcheting. But things seem good for me now.

First off, the ergonomics are great. I noticed my grip instantly became more relaxed when I started using this mouse compared to my old one. Only potential problem with ergonomics is the pronounced uppermost bump. It fits fine in my hands with slightly more pressure than the rest of the mouse, but it could get in the way if you have smaller hands. The overall size is perfect for my medium-large sized hands and claw grip.But my favourite part is the side scroll wheel combined with the Logitech Options software. I can find a use for the side scroll wheel in almost every application, and the Options software makes it super easy to set application specific mappings.I also don't have any issues with the scroll wheel aside from SmartShift not responding well. SmartShift lets the scroll wheel spin freely but the page doesn't always scroll with it, so I just keep it off and it works a lot better. The scroll wheel is probably the best one I've ever used. The button above it allows you to quickly switch between smooth and click-to-click scrolling. I use smooth scrolling for relaxed use and click-to-click when I need to be more accurate.

This is a gret mouse.  Installation was very simple and it allows for several customizations.  Not only you can customize the buttons ingeneral but also depending on the appication you're running.A minor issue is that it won't work as a wired mouse when connecting to USB charger cable; it still needs the wireless (or bluetooth) connectivity; battery last long enough so it's not a big deal anyway.

I really like this mouse. Expensive but I am glad I purchased it. I use a mouse so much in my life, I want it to be good quality. Works on any surface, scroll wheel to move up and down, scroll wheel on the side to move left to right. Feels really good in your hand. Charging port seems solid and it is easy to charge and battery lasts weeks at a time (even at my office). Really cool is it works with multiple computers. I don't think I could ask for anything more with thisWorth the price? I think so
This mouse is awesome! Perfect for gaming and working

A product should be easy to use or comfortable for its user but this mouse is so bulky if you small hands. Don't buy this if you have normal small hands. I don't recommend this. Do not intend to play games with this kind of mouse, it is an ergonomic mouse for productivity work and, as such, it does its job very well.The surface that makes contact with the des is raised of 3-4 mm which might not be enjoyable for people who prefer to leave a bit of their palm on the desk but I have been able to cope with that pretty easily.
Purchased it for its reliability and fast response. Works very well but expensive.

As a software professional I've bought A LOT of mice over the years.  Generally I haven't much liked wireless mice for various reasons.  But I wanted a way to use one mouse (and keyboard - I have the Logitech Ergo K860) between three computers and I have to say, the pair are really good.  I used the Logitech Unifying USB Receiver (USB dongle) instead of Bluetooth, and I use these two devices across Linux and Window computers without any trouble at all.

You can't go wrong with Logitech products. This MX Master 3 is their top-end desktop mouse. If you are a heavy desktop PC user, you won't be disappointed with this solidly built mouse. I like that it comes with both wireless and Bluetooth modes. I prefer the Bluetooth option as the USB receiver is not required.
Very comfertable and i love it but not the best for gaming

I fell in love with this mouse especially the side scroll wheel. The ability to customize all the buttons is great. Definitely recommend this mouse to anyone and it feels great holding this mouse.Only thing I miss with my previous Logitech m720 is the long battery life. But regardless this mouse charges quickly so its not to bad. Can't go back to my other mouse or any other mouse.It's great for work for use with Ms teams, pdfs, zoom, power point, photoshop, web browsing. I occasionally move around from a wood desk to a glass office desk and this mouse works well on glass and other surfaces with no issues. Definitely not a gaming mouse, there are others for this.This mouse can connect up to 3 pcs and also has flow so you can transition between your computers easily while on the same network.

No dislikes so far. I have both the MX Master 2S and the 3. The Master 2S had an annoying tendency to activate the side screen changing buttons just from resting the thumb on it (which is a natural resting place for the thumb), so I disabled it on the 2S. No problems so far on the 3. Had the 3 for one week so far and all is well at this point.
I've only been using it for a few weeks but I love this mouse. Lots of functionality and customizability, comfortable, and it improves productivity if you set it up to suit your workflow.
Excellent, fits well in my hands and I love all the customizations. Highly recommends it

I use this mouse everyday. It works great with Macs and PCs. It has a button on the bottom that allows the user to quickly switch between different devices (can store up to 3 devices at a time).

The mouse feels great in my hand, is very responsive, and has crazy long battery life. Unlike an Apple mouse, you can also use it while it's charging. While you can remap the forward/back and side buttons to lots of commands, most video games won't recognize those commands as valid inputs: so you can use it for productivity OR gaming, but not both.
Hands down, this is the best mouse I have ever used.  Worth every penny.

I'm using it for software development, very handy.However, there is room for improvement.The button on the bottom feels useless, but it doesn't bother me.And the thumb roller (horizontal scroll) is too slow... it's easier to scroll with the scroll bar rather than using this roller.Other than that everything is fine. Mouse is comfortable and can be used while charging. Programming 8 hours a day, highly recommend.

Perfect for everyone, games might want something with a better dpi, but this is great for everything and i game with it. Better hooked up with USB dongle than the Bluetooth for reliability. Best mouse I have ever used.

Pros:- Can connect up to 3 devices to the mouse, and then switch between them with the bottom button- Mouse buttons can be programmed for specific programs- Software for the mouse is simple and easy to use- Side Scroll Wheel is great for vertical scrolling- Very comfortable mouse to use- Battery life is great- Nice that it use USB-C for ChargingCons:- Would be nice if you could assign another button on the mouse to be able to switch between devices- Cost- The Latency for Bluetooth on the mouse is okay, but you may sometimes see some studded when moving the mouse. Perfect mouse for work / business.Only thing i found amazing was that to switch devices the button is in the bottom. I switch devices every few minutes and that part is inconvenient. So i had to just use 2 mice.

One of the largest mice one can find on the market. Fits big hands, thought, I would prefer to be even bigger. Has a lot of configurable features, very smooth operations, light.Ergonomic design is great, thought in my case this design caused strain on one of my wrist ligaments - it is the way I use mouse.Scroll wheelThe feature I love the most is free-wheeling scroll (scroll wheel is very light in operation), its tactile feedback. The scroll button push (ie. mouse middle-button) needs stronger pressure, which makes it extremely comfortable in use - operations on the scroll wheel are not interrupted by accidental middle-button clicks, as in in light-push scroll wheel designs, which saves your wrist ligaments.I wish all mice on the market had this design.Note: I haven't used it games, mainly programming work
Battery life is fantastic, with an average use of 10 hours a day it can last up to a week and then only takes an hour or two to charge fully.

Logitech has always been known for their wireless keyboards and mice, and this one is no exception. In 2016, Logitech was the first to create a wireless technology that has no interference with other wireless devices, and can respond as fast as a wired mouse plugged in via USB. Ever since, Logitech's wireless Logitech MX Master 3 mice have been outstanding in terms of performance.
